entry.title: How To Wear A Sports Cap With A Ponytail
entry.content:
This is a guide to wearing a sports cap with a ponytail.

You will need:
  1. A sports cap
  2. A hair tie
 Of course, you could just plonk the sports cap on your head, but that's not a great look, nor is it comfortable when it's hot.

Alternatively, you could pull hair back and then secure it with your cap, but again, it's not a great option.

Another option is to tie a very low ponytail that hugs your nape, but in the heat that can get very uncomfortable, especially if you have thick, curly hair.

Yet another option is to tie a fairly low ponytail and then pull it through the opening at the back of your cap, but if your cap has velcro that can pretty painful and in order to get it neat and tight, you'd have to readjust the hair tie anyway.

So here's what I do.

  1. Twist your hair as if you were preparing a chiffon and then wrap it over your index finger, holding it between your thumb and middle finger.
  2. Place the cap over your head.
  3. Feed the tightly wrapped hair through the opening and let go.
  4. Then apply the hair tie.
Et voilà! A tight, neat ponytail with no fuss.

Let's see it from the side:
Twist your hair as if you were preparing a chiffon and then wrap it over your index finger, holding it between your thumb and middle finger.
Place the cap over your head.
Feed the tightly wrapped hair through the opening and let go.
Then apply the hair tie.
Et voilà! A tight, neat ponytail with no fuss.

Thanks for watching and let me know if this helps you.

Thank you! To answer your question about this line:

"With only a couple of slips, which the casual listener never notices anyway, Odessa finished the song with a delighted [should that be "delightful"] trill?"

What I wanted to convey is that Odessa took delight in finishing the song with a trill, i.e. "delighted". Odessa is not an accomplished pianist, so her judgement as to the use of the trill might not be perfect, but she really likes adding it when she can. I suppose it's like a guitarist who likes to slide or hammer, even if the music doesn't always call for those techniques...

By contrast, a trill is either *delightful* if it is played at the right time and executed properly, or it is *not delightful* if it's poorly timed or executed.

So I think "delighted" conveys the meaning, but it's a great question nevertheless.

entry.title: FAI Symptoms in My Left Hip
entry.content:
A few weeks ago I described how I have been making an effort to use my left side as much as possible, especially when picking things up and reaching for items.

Over the last couple of days my left hamstring complex has been unusually tight.  I did tissue work on all the major suspects on my left side, but to no avail.

Moreover, when I go into a deep wide squat, now my left hip joint feels compressed.

What is going on?

This morning I bent down to reach for something from the floor with my left hand, and my left hamstrings were unhappy as was my left hip.  I thought, "my body is trying to tell me something, but I can't work out what I'm doing wrong.  It must be related to how I use my left side."

A while later, I picked up something with my right hand and noticed that my right glutes activated as I bent forward.  "Hmm," I thought to myself, "I don't recall such glute activation on my left side."

I tested the left and found that I don't really activate my glutes when I bend over my left to pick up something from the floor.  So what do I do instead?  You guessed it, I hang on my hamstrings instead and let them do all the work of stabilising me.  No prizes for guessing what that does to my hamstrings over the days and weeks of using my left side as much as possible.

Next, I bent over my left and consciously activated my glutes... No pain, no compression, no discomfort.

Before using the FAI Fix, this could have prompted a visit to the physiotherapist, the doctor, the surgeon, etc.  Now, I am equipped to listen to what my body tells me -- even if it takes a while for the message to filter through -- and I have the tools to address this issue before it gets out of hand.

It's a small simple improvement in and of itself, but the ramifications of this minor correction are the difference between success and failure in training, and living with pain or without it.

entry.title: Chapter I: Climbing the Mountain
entry.content:
Image from doppingqnk on http://deviantart.net/
Bridge #90 ended on a small cliff edge on the side of a mountain, illuminated by a lonely Victorian street lamp.  As Odessa and Praetorious Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) hopped off, the final slat burst into flames and fizzled away into the abyss.  A cold wind moaned.

"This rock feels strange under my paws," Trousers said.

Odessa knelt down; it felt warm and rubbery; she tried to recall what it reminded her of, but her mind went blank.

She stood up facing the mountain.  A narrow path wound around the corner to their left.

From the depths of the mountain an amused chuckle boomed through the rock.  "What makes you think that you can ascend me, you little specks?"

Trousers leapt into Odessa's arms, his hackles raised.

"Come," the mountain said sternly and a large hole opened up in front of them, "don't scamper about until I fling you into the abyss.  I've been expecting you."

Odessa smelled cinnamon-laced baking.  She took a step towards the opening, which was about the size a large window, just above her head.

"That's it, my little ones," the mountain whispered, "we've got everything you'll need."

Trousers tensed.  "Something about this makes my whiskers twitch," he said, "we ought to move on from here."

Odessa stopped.  "Thank you for your kind offer, Mr Mountain," she began, "but we can't stay.  We -- "

"What! How dare you?!" the mountain bellowed, "No-one can refuse me!  Get in there this instant!"

A blast of icy wind blew in from the abyss; Odessa felt herself being thrown off balance towards the opening.  She got down on all fours and crawled towards the wall.  A set of long, stick-like arms sprang out, writhing like a spider's legs, snatching wildly at the air above her head.  The arms and hands were deathly white, with long, red, sharp fingernails.  Odessa couldn't smell the warm cinnamon anymore; instead, a faint stench of gore.

A low, wordless moan poured out of the opening, and with every passing second another voice was added to its chorus.  Before long, it sounded as if the whole mountain was crying and shouting and hissing and rasping in the screaming wind.

Odessa crawled along the wall towards the path, the wind barraging her face, until she turned the corner and got out of the wind.  The voices died down and the opening snapped shut, yanking in the writhing hands.

Odessa collapsed on to her back and lay gasping for a while.  Trousers emerged from her jacket and looked around timidly.  He sat down on her chest, sank his chin, and licked the front of his chest vigorously.  She looked up at him but he averted his gaze.  She reached out and stroked him reassuringly.  He stopped his grooming and lay down with his front paws near the base of her throat.

"Thank you for warning me," she said.

He mumbled a bashful reply and purred into her chest.

After some time, they followed the winding path up the mountain.

The mountain teemed with sunken faces and curious eyes; all along the way they were followed by moans and hisses and unintelligible whispers.  Grasping hands slithered from crevices in the wall and sprouted from the ground underfoot.  After one red-taloned hand nearly latched on to his tail, Odessa ignored Trousers' protests and plonked him in her bag, to keep an eye on her belongings, of course.

The path ended at a crater with walls the height of Odessa's head.  In front of them was a narrow opening in the wall, just wide enough for Odessa to squeeze through.

A face took shape in the wall near the gate and called out to them:

"Pssst, don't go any further!"

"Why not?"

"That's where the Man in the Mountain lives."

"He's just the man we've been looking for."

"No, you don't understand!" he exclaimed and his eyes flitted back and forth, as if to check that the coast was clear.  "It’s perfect in there.  Once you're in, you'll never leave!"

"I don't understand," Odessa replied.  "Wouldn't that be a wonderful thing?"

The face contorted in disagreement.

"The clever people around me always said we should live in a world where everyone is equal and everyone is taken care of.  I never questioned it.  I always thought it unfair that some people are beautiful, some are rich, some are clever, some are strong; some have a good life, some have a hard life.  So I came here with my friends because we heard that everyone is equal and everyone is taken care of here."

"And is it?"

"Yes! Can't you see?  He's given us everything we asked for!"

All along the wall faces emerged like blisters on burned skin.  They were not identical, but from a distance they all had the same sunken lifeless eyes, the same grey skin, the same sharp teeth, the same miserable expression.

"What are you talking about, Comrade?" a nearby face asked, "have you started talking about life outside the mountain again?  Do you want everybody to just die in the middle of the street?"

"No, that's not what I'm saying at all!" Comrade said.  "I'm saying that we all got what we asked for, but it's not what we thought it would be."

"You need to grow up and accept that life here is as good as it could be," another face said.

"We have coffee and cake here!"

"I don't even like coffee and cake," Comrade replied.

"Just because you don't like it doesn't mean we can't have our coffee and cake," another voice jumped in.

"That's not what I'm saying at all," Comrade retorted, "What I'm trying to say is --"

"I'm offended by that!" said another voice.

"Me too!"

"So am I!"

"Yes, I'm offended as well!"

An army of long arms with red-taloned hands slithered from the wall and pulled him out of the wall up to his waist.  They swarmed his body, latching on to every of piece of him.  Comrade started to scream but was cut short as the hands ripped him apart and directed chunks of his flesh and bone towards the salivating, razor-toothed faces around him.  Before long, there was nothing left of Comrade except for a bloody stump in the wall, which suddenly swallowed his remains and closed itself, leaving a perfectly smooth section where he used to be.

The other faces chomped noisily for a bit and then sank into the wall.
Odessa looked for another way to leave the mountain, but her only option was the opening in the wall.  With her heart in her mouth, she tip-toed towards it and squeezed through.


The Odessia by Alexander Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://theodessia.blogspot.com.au/.

entry.title: VLOOKUP in Google Sheets is sensitive to trailing spaces
entry.content: If VLOOKUP can't find something that's obvously there, and you know you've formatted Column 1 to plain text, make sure you don't have trailing spaces in your source data.

entry.title: How To Become More "Flexible"
entry.content:
Most of us would like to be more "flexible", but most people (as far as I can tell) do not know what this means.

Definitions

Do you want to swing your leg higher in football or dancing? Bend over further? Swing your arm out further? Twist and turn through a greater range? That's dynamic flexibility.
This football player was stretching very dynamically; no external resistance here.
Do you want to achieve the splits or go flat on the floor in a static stretch?  That's static passive flexibility.
Thomas Kurz, an oracle of flexibility. 
Do you want to raise your leg high and keep it up in the air? That's static active flexibility.
This martial artists are keeping their legs up in the air without assistance.
Although they are related, each type of flexibility is different and must be trained for specifically.

Your static passive flexibility in a given range is as far as you can go, with all the assistance from external force that your body will permit.  Your dynamic and static active ranges are a subset of your static passive range, and most people's flexibility can be represented by this venn diagramme:


What This Means For You

To Increasing Dynamic Flexibility

  1. Maximise your dynamic flexibility within your current static passive range through dynamic stretching; OR
  2. Increase your static passive range through PNF stretching AND dynamic stretching
This will allow you to kick higher, swing your arm out wider, bend and twist further in a movement, etc.

To Increase Static Passive Flexibility

  1. Maximise your static active flexibility within your current static passive range through static active stretching; OR
  2. Increase your static passive range AND static active stretching
This will allow you to hold your leg up higher without assistance, reach out further with your arm, bend and twist in a static position further.

To Increase Your Static Passive Range

  1. Condition the muscle with resistance training through the entire range of motion.
  2. Static passive stretching.
  3. P.N.F. (proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation) of stretching, commonly known as "contract-release".
This will both increase your potential in the other two categories and translate into getting deeper and wider in your stretches -- splits, bends, bridges, etc.

Defining Your Goals

What does all this mean in practice?

It usually means that, in addition to maximising your dynamic and static active flexibility, you want to increase your static passive range.

Not only do you want to kick higher, you want to do the splits; not only do you want to bend further in dancing, you want to do a bridge, etc.

Not only will achieving these static passive stretches give you a greater tensile range to work with, but they are milestones in and of themselves.

So How Do I Get There?

A good start would be a previous post of mine on the topic:
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/2015/12/isolated-stretches-vs-compound-stretches.html

And of course, to familiarise yourself with the work of Thomas Kurz:
https://tomkurz.wordpress.com

And finally, a great system for getting to know your limitations and how to overcome them is the FAI Fix developed by Matt Hsu at Upright Health and Shane Dowd at Legacy Athletics:
https://www.thefaifix.com

Further Definitions

The following definitions are taken from Thomas Kurz's book, Stretching Scientifically:

Flexibility: Flex + Ability = Flexibility. Where as Flex is to bend or to resist breaking, and Ability is a skill or talent. Flexibility becomes the skill of controlling the range of motion and movement capacity of your physical structure. Flexibility is developed by special exercises called stretches, which involve the elongation of muscles, connective tissues, and other tissues.

Types of flexibility

There are six types of flexibility. They are classified based on the muscle's action and whether or not there is an external force acting to maintain or aid an increase in the range of motion. They include:
  1. Dynamic active flexibility (just using the muscles of the moving body part);
  2. Dynamic passive flexibility below the pain threshold (only using as much external assistance as needed to reach the painless limit of motion);
  3. Dynamic passive flexibility over the pain threshold and up to pain tolerance (using as much external assistance as needed to reach the maximal limit of motion permitted by pain tolerance);
  4. Static active flexibility (just using the muscles of the stretched body part to hold a stretched position);
  5. Static passive flexibility below the pain threshold (only using as much external assistance as needed to reach the painless maximum stretch); and
  6. Static passive flexibility up to pain tolerance (using as much external assistance as needed to reach the painless maximal stretch permitted by pain tolerance).

entry.title: Pirmas darbo pokalbis baigę
entry.content:
Aš bandau gauti darbą, ir šiandien buvo pirmasis pokalbis.
Yra gana gerai, nes vyras iš įmonės domėjosi sužinoti daugiau apie mane. Klausė daug klausimų apie darbą, ir man paaiškino ką jie daro ir ko ieško naujame bendradarbyje.

Jis sakė kad yra gera galimybė vėl kalbėti. Dabar turi aptarti su jo bendradarbiais.

Rytoj bus antrasis pokalbis ir poryt trečiasis.

Nežinau kaip man veiks, bet darau mano geriausias.

entry.title: How I Am Studying Lithuanian
entry.content:
CAVEAT

This post is titled "How I Am Studying" rather than "How I Learned" Lithuanian, for two reasons:
  1. Firstly, I do not yet speak Lithuanian fluently.
  2. Secondly, even when I attain fluency in the language, I will continue to study it according to this method, which has proven itself time and time again.

OVERVIEW: LEARNING LANGUAGE THE HARD WAY

Most students of a language want as quickly as possible to build up their vocabularies, but when it comes to the mechanics of the language -- grammar, syntax, morphology, etc. -- the general approach ranges from picking up bits and pieces along the way to paying lip service to it.
My method may be called "Learning Lithuanian the Hard Way" because I invested about one hundred hours in studying Lithuanian grammar, syntax, morphology, and pronuncation.  Now, after three months of intense preparation, I am starting to focus on vocabulary, writing, and speaking.
This method requires discipline, patience, and attention to detail; it may be likened to the physical training of an elite athlete, and as such in almost all cases requires the supervision of a language coach.

INTRODUCTION: WHAT IS LANGUAGE?

For our purposes, all languages are composed of speaking and listening, to which we add writing and reading.  Bear in mind that the written language merely represents the spoken language, for this insight will help you greatly in understanding the forms of words, pronunciation, and elegant arrangement of words in a sentence.
These four primary language activities and their variations are ranked in order of difficulty:

  1. Reading: The easiest. The entire context is available, there is no pressure to produce language, nor is there time pressure.
  2. Listening: The second easiest. Most of the context is available in the conversation, there is no pressure to produce language and time pressure is minimal.
  3. Writing: The second hardest. No context is available for ascertaining the meaning of individual words and there is pressure to produce the language, but there is no time pressure.
  4. Speaking: The hardest. No context is available for ascertaining the meaning of individual words, there is pressure to produce language, and there is intense time pressure.
If we expand this into the variations of these activities, the ranking is roughly the same:

Reading (Alone) Silently

The easiest language activity is reading silently, for there is no time pressure nor do you have to make the effort of producing the sounds of the language.

Reading Alone Out Loud

The second-easiest language activity is reading out loud without an audience.  There is still no time pressure, you can read as slowly as you like, and you can repeat words, phrases, sentences, and even entire paragraphs as many times as you like without any pressure from your audience.

Reading Out Loud to a Private Audience

The third-easiest language activity is reading out loud with a private audience (as opposed to a public audience, which places much greater pressure on you), which can be either another person or a recording device.  With a private audience present, there is the most minimal time pressure, but you can still read very slowly and carefully.  With a private audience you begin to feel the pressure of performance, and you may initially feel stage fright.  The only solution is to keep on practising in front of a sympathetic private audience until you get over it.

Listening to a Recording or Private Reading with the Text to Hand

The easiest form of listening is where you have total control of the audio and can follow along on the page.  For example, listening to an audiobook and reading the book at the same time.  In this manner you both see and hear the language, can control the pace, re-listen to a section, make notes on the page, etc.  The time pressure is minimal and there is no pressure to produce the language or interact with someone.  Another alternative is a sympathetic native speaker reading out loud to you slowly and clearly.  If your reader knows what he is doing, this is far superior to a recording.

Listening to a Recording or Private Reading without the Text to Hand

This is significantly harder than reading along with the audio, but only insofar as you do not recognise the words.  As you train your ear to the natural rhythm of the language and recognise common phrases and constructions, listening will become easier, for you will naturally infer the meaning of unfamiliar words.

Listening to an Interlocutor

The next step up from listening to scripted speech is to make sense of a conversation partner.  As you have the context of the conversation, you more easily infer the meaning of unfamiliar words, and a sympathetic speaker will speak slowly and simply; nevertheless, you have to keep up with the conversation.

Listening in on a Conversation

The most difficult form of listening is making sense of speech that is not directed at you, for which you do not have the context.  This includes listening to other people's conversations, watching films in the language (made easier by subtitles), etc.  Because you are not the conversation partner of a sympathetic speaker, his speech is typically faster, the words are less clearly pronounced, and you can not signal to him to repeat or explain an unfamiliar word.

Writing with the Aid of a Dictionary

Any kind of writing requires you to do all the heavy lifting of constructing sentences, i.e. not only summoning the words, but inflecting them and arranging them.  In writing there is no time pressure to speak of, and with a dictionary, you can write sentences mostly in Lithuanian and then translate the remainder.

Writing without the Aid of a Dictionary

This form of writing demands the creative use of your vocabulary: you have to reduce your ideas to their essence in order to express in the simplest terms possible.

Private conversation with a Sympathetic Interlocutor

The hardest of the primary language activities is speaking, for it entails all the pressures of producing language and must be done in real time.  A sympathetic conversation partner can lighten your load by giving you time to find your words and supply you with the key word here and there.

General Conversation and Public Speaking

The second-most difficult language activities are speaking freely in a conversation and public speaking.  The difficulty of each depends on how comfortable you are in front of a crowd, but the cognitive load is the same: You have to produce language in real time without assistance.

Getting Angry at Someone

The hardest language activity is getting into an argument with someone.  To all the other stressors of producing language is added the heat of emotion, which transforms a private conversation into the equivalent of a public performance with a hostile audience.

RESOURCES

The online resources are so paltry, and the Lithuanian language is so complicated, that learning to speak Lithuanian autodidactically is practically impossible without supreme motivation, talent, deep knowledge of language, and an advanced method of study.

Having said that, the following have proven enormously useful to me:
  • Google Translate (USE WITH EXTREME CAUTION): https://translate.google.com/
  • The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian grammar: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_grammar
  • The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian declension: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_declension
  • The Debesėlis Lithuanian course: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/courses/lt
  • Cooljugater for Lithuanian Verbs: http://cooljugator.com/lt/list/all
  • The Accentuator Tool from Vytauto Didžiojo Universiteto: http://tekstynas.vdu.lt/page.xhtml;jsessionid=B9B35DD0D70596608023D1295B2BF16C?id=accentuator-tool
  • This declension tool: http://morfologija.lt/
  • Google Lithuania: https://www.google.lt/
  • Lithuanian Wiktionary: https://lt.wiktionary.org/
  • And most significantly, the Lithuanian translation of the Little Prince, which is my language-learning rosetta stone: http://ebiblioteka.mkp.emokykla.lt/kuriniai/mazasis_princas/,format.pdf
There is also an audiobook version of this text "Mažasis Princas", but you'll have to hunt around for it.

TOOLS

  • A5 exercise book
  • Black pen
  • Blue pen
  • Red pen
  • Green pen
  • Highlighter
  • Small ruler
  • Flash cards
  • Flash card container

GETTING STARTED

Step One: Study the grammar

I printed out and read through the entirety of these articles
The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian grammar: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_grammar
The Infogalactic article on Lithuanian declension: https://infogalactic.com/info/Lithuanian_declension
The Debesėlis Lithuanian course: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/courses/lt
I read and re-read until I was satisfied I understood broadly how Lithuanian works -- noun declension, verbal conjugation, adjectival inflexion, participles, etc.

Step Two: Find Your Rosetta Stone

'Le Petit Prince' by Antoine de Saint-Exupery is marvellously well suited to language learning.  It is a simple and short, and contains simple dialogue, repetition, core vocabulary, and advanced vocabulary.  It is accessible to both children and adults and can be read many times over without becoming stale.  I have read it in French, English, German, Italian, Hebrew, Dutch, and have used it extensively to learn Lithuanian.
If the 'Le Petit Prince' is not for you, use any text you like, but make sure it is simple enough for you to read in a foreign language and enjoyable enough to be read a hundred times over.

Step Three: Add Stress Marks to Your Rosetta Stone

Added to all the other things that make Lithuanian difficult is the seemingly unpredictable pattern of its floating stress placement.  My initial plan was to listen to the audiobook and note the stresses for the entire book, which would be an excellent exercise, but very laborious.
Luckily, I was able to feed the entirety of the text through the Accentuator Tool from Vytauto Didžiojo Universiteto: http://tekstynas.vdu.lt/page.xhtml;jsessionid=B9B35DD0D70596608023D1295B2BF16C?id=accentuator-tool
I then pasted the accentuated text into a document and turned it into a book: I printed the whole text and had it bound.

Step Four: Extract the Verbs*

* The essential part of speech in all Indo-European languages is the verb, for it is the engine of the sentence; if you are studying Hungarian or Finnish for example, the nouns seem to contain more essential information.  When in doubt, focus on the verbs.

I read the Introduction and Chapters One and Two, and with the aid of Google Translate identified all of the verbs.  On flash cards I recorded the essential details of each verb and the passage in which the verb was used; on the back of each flash card I recorded all the variations of the verb that can be produced by adding prefixes.  In this manner I recorded 109 core verbs, totalling around 500 different verbs.

Step Five: Read Your Rosetta Stone Out Loud As Much As Possible

I have continued to read and re-read the book "Mažasis Princas" out loud.  Most of the time, I do so on my own, but on weekends I read to my beautiful fiancée, who at first put up with all my mistakes and mispronunciations, and now enjoys my readings.  This step runs in parallel with all the remaining steps.

Step Six: Conjugate Your Verbs

In my exercise book, I conjugated all 109 of my newly acquired core verbs.  This task took me about 40 hours and I can now confidently conjugate any regular verb in Lithuanian that I have the essential information for -- infinitive, third-person singular, third-person plural.

Step Seven: Nominal Declension Drills

I returned to the flash cards, identified the nouns in the passages I recorded, and wrote all their forms -- singular and plural.

Step Eight: Adjectival Inflexion Drills

I returned to the flash cards, identified the adjectives in the passages I recorded, and wrote out all their forms -- singular and plural, masculine and feminine.

Step Nine: Learn the Numbers

I studied this lesson on numbers on Debesėlis: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/lesson/temp/221

Step Ten: Learn the Pronouns

I studied this lesson on pronouns on Debesėlis: http://www.debeselis.net/lessons/lesson/temp/223

Step Eleven: Participle Declension

Lithuanian participles are much easier to understand in light of noun declensions and adjectival inflexions.  They are simply verbs that are used as adjectives and adverbs, and thus inherit both the information pertaining to verbs (tense, number) and to adjectives. (Declension, gender, number)

Step Twelve: Review

After three months and about 100 hours of preparation, planning, and exercises, I am now ready to start "using" Lithuanian.  I still need to learn some irregular verbs, nouns, and adjectives, and there remain some aspects of Lithuanian grammar that I have not practised enough to use confidently on the fly, but I now have a solid foundation.  I have profound understanding of mechanics of the language, and can construct grammatically correct sentences.  Without ever focusing on learning new words in Lithuanian, I have nevertheless acquired a good foundational vocabulary and must now put it to use in writing.

Step Thirteen: Write Essays, Learn from My Mistakes

The best way to expand my vocabulary is to write about diverse topics in Lithuanian and to learn the words that I have to look up in the dictionary.  This way, instead of learning words that I will not use, I learn only the words that I need to know and am likely to use frequently.  This shall be my core vocabulary on which my expanded vocabulary is to be built.
The process for each composition is as follows:
  1. Write in Lithuanian as much as I can without a dictionary, and leave words and phrases I do not know in [brackets].
  2. With a dictionary to hand, fill in the [gaps].
  3. Submit the essay to a native Lithuanian for correction.
  4. Have the native Lithuanian re-write the essay more elegantly, with authentic Lithuanian turns of phrase.
  5. Thank the Lithuanian profusely for his time.
  6. Take note of the corrections.
  7. Study the re-written essay and learn the new words and turns of phrase.

Step Fourteen: Complete the Study of Lithuanian Grammar

I will go through whatever resources are available and make sure that I am familiar with all aspects of Lithuanian grammar.

Step Fifteen: Write, Speak, Read, and Listen.

From this point on, all that is required is to use the language as much as possible and to learn the idiom of the language.  I might continue to use flash cards, or I might just keep a notebook.  Whereas a novice of the language needs to refer to a complete table of declensions or conjugations, an expert needs only a single datum to fill in a gap in his knowledge.  Over time, I will instinctively note the particulars of new vocabulary without having to write anything down and I will get a feel for authentic, elegant turns of phrase.  This process will span the rest of my life, but I predict most of my learning will take place in the next three years.

entry.title: Hello, World: I Have FAI
entry.content:
Dragonfly at Melbourne Calisthenics
In spite of my best efforts, I have always had poor flexibility, lower back pain, tight hamstrings, and a general sense of helpless discomfort in my hips.  I am a very healthy, active, fit, 30-year-old man with a fine musculature and not a hint of a medical condition that would account for my physical problems.  And yet, something always seemed awry.

After probably 15 years of struggling with hip and leg flexibility, a parade of health specialists including doctors, physiotherapists, masseurs and masseuses, an acupuncturist, and everything in between, hundreds of hours, thousands of dollars, innumerable abortive attempts to improve in these areas, and a pervading sense that something just isn't working... I believe I know what's wrong.

An X-ray of both my hips, taken on the 15th of December 2014, reveals a femoro-acetabular impingement due to a large CAM lesion on the right femoral head and a small CAM lesion on the left femoral head.  As far as I can tell, both hip sockets are of normal shaped and width, so were it not for the lesions on both femoral heads I would have full range of flexion and rotation.

Furthermore, an ultrasound scan of my right hip does not reveal any damage or abnormality in the soft tissue around my right hip and groin, although an MRI (scheduled for Tuesday 23rd December) is required to investigate a labral tear.  I believe the labrum on my right hip is torn, quite possibly very badly, as I have suffered from chronic inflammation of the area for years.

Without efficacious treatment, I shall have arthritis in my right hip within a few years, and shall require hip replacement surgery at a pathetically early stage in my life.

As far as I can tell, the only efficacious treatment is surgery, and the best form of surgery is an arthroscopic osteoplasty to shave down the CAM lesion and chrondoplasty to repair the damaged labrum.  If the above be true, I require this procedure in both hips, but I do not yet know whether it is practicable or even feasible to have both hips treated in the same operation.  If so, I'd prefer to get it over and done with, but at the very least correcting the femoro-acetabular impingement in my right hip will buy me some time.

My plan is as follows:

PRE-OPERATION
  1. 23rd December 2014: Get an MRI to check for the extent of labral damage in my right hip
  2. 24th December 2014: Discuss the results with my doctor (general practitioner) and get a referral to a surgeon who specialises in the treatement of femoro-acetabular impingement.
  3. See said specialist and ascertain whether there is any reason I should NOT proceed with arthroscopic osteoplasty and chrondoplasty.
  4. Schedule the operation as soon as possible.
  5. Get in touch with the person who will give me post-operative rehabilitation exercises, learn what they are, and perform them daily in order to be as familiar with them as possible for my recovery.
POST-OPERATION
  1. Perform the rehabilitation exercises religiously.
  2. Avoid undue physical exertions.
  3. Focus on my work and studies.
  4. Regularly update my FAI blog and vlog.
    During this period, I will avoid activities that aggravate my condition, including ball sports, gymnastics, tricking, parkour, etc.
    However, I will maintain my routine of gentle running, dancing (swing, blues, zouk, salsa, bachata) and make my home away from home the Melbourne Calisthenics gym, run by my personal trainer, Alexander Jenkins, who is a knowledgeable athlete and a fine motivator  (http://www.melbournecalisthenics.com.au)
    Also, I have a book of introductory floor pilates exercises that I always meant to perform daily, so now is as good a time as any to incorporate them into my morning routine.

    Although I shall dearly miss my gymnastic activities, it is my heart's desire and my intention to build up my body with the view of returning to these pursuits by the end of 2015 and with a view to a happier, longer, pain-free life.

    FINAL THOUGHTS FOR TODAY
    I have many thoughts and feelings on this topic.  I hope that this blog will serve as a resource for other people suffering from this grossly undiagnosed condition, and provide encouragement to others who are going through it.

    Feel free to comment and get in touch with me.

    ---
    This is a journal entry from Alex's FAI Journal. For past and future posts, please visit http://faijournal.blogspot.com

For comparison's sake, here is the original description:

She wore soft, flat-soled boots, cargo pants with a simple leather belt, a fitted T-shirt, and a lightweight long-sleeved top with the sleeves usually rolled up. She carried her belongings in a spacious backpack, with lots of pockets and compartments. Her long tight black curls cascaded over her shoulders and bobbled energetically when she moved. Her eyes were the colour of dark oak and were set underneath a pair of bold black eyebrows; she had a habit of scanning every detail. When she focused her attention on you, you could almost feel the information being syphoned. When she daydreamed, which she did often, she tended to tilt her head to one side and look up out of the corner of her left eye with slightly parted lips. And when someone she especially loved held her close, she liked to purr softly, sometimes with a French R, sometimes trilled, and brush his cheek with hers.

entry.title: Sinister Dexterity or Dextrous Sinisterness: Pick Things Up With Your Other Hand
entry.content:
I being right-handed, it has always been my habit to pick things up with right hand.  This means it has always been my habit to place my weight on my right foot, bend over my right side, reach with my right arm, etc.  If something be on the floor, that means lunging with my right foot forward -- always my right foot forward -- or squatting with my weight over my right foot... You get the idea.

In light of this thought, a week ago I made a conscious decision to pick things up with my left hand as much as possible, if not exclusively.

After a week I can report the following:
  1. My left quads are getting much more of a work-out every day.
  2. The chain of muscles running all the way from my left hip to my left hand has been getting much more of a work out every day.
  3. I am getting better at balancing on my left foot.
  4. I am developing a better sense of what my left hip does when I move in my daily life.
As to the title, "dexter" means right and "sinister" left in Latin.  The sense of skillfulness in dexterous comes from the recognition that most people (nine out of ten, I am told) are better at doing things with their right hands.  This gives us such expressions as "right-hand man" and "to be on the right side" of things. The sense of malevolence in sinister comes from the superstitious association of bad omens, evil, and inferiority with the left hand side of things.

Therefore, in my coinage, to train your left side is to develop "sinister dexterity"; conversely, to train your right, "dexterous sinisterness".  Those who understand the joke should be valued as life-long friends.

This blog and all contents herein are available under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Licence. Please share freely and let me know if this helps anyone.

entry.title: EC2 Set Up, Now To Set Up Jira!
entry.content:
It turns out that it's a pain to run Jira on a micro instance.
I have purchased a larger instance, which will cost me about $10 per month to run, but I consider it an investment.



I'm going to set up the LAMP stack and install Jira on it.
It's still on Ubuntu 14.04



Let's see if I can do a distro upgrade on SSH



I live on the edge...



I'll take the risk!



Upgrade complete



My Apache2 web server is alive!



It took me a while to understand the security, it should have been obvious but it's all part of the learning curve



An EC2 instance by default is open only on Port 22, i.e. SSH, so you can't log in to its server home page in the browser (of course!)
I had to create a new security group and open the necessary ports
But there it is:
http://52.62.253.103/
I shan't get to installing Jira today, but I'll do it tomorrow
I learned some new important things today about managing an Amazon EC2 instance so I'm happy

PHP is set up too; check it out!


And so is PHPMyAdmin

entry.title: How To Remotely View Provision-ISR CCTV in Your Browser
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber

You can log into a Provision-ISR DVR or NVR or even a stand-alone IP camera via Internet Explorer or Firefox on Windows, or Safari on MacOSX.

Windows

Internet Explorer

Make sure that your Security Settings allow the ActiveX plug-in.
Next, go to the external IP or DDNS address provided by your installer.
You will see a screen with a light blue background.  Your browser should prompt you to run an ActiveX control.  Authorise your browser to do so, and when this screen appears, enter your username and password.

Firefox

Your CCTV system’s web address will take you to a light-blue page with a large download button and a refresh button.  Click the download button to download the file Webclient.exe.
Close Firefox.
Open Windows Explorer, locate the downloaded Webclient.exe and run it.
A terminal window will open briefly and then close again.
Re-open Firefox and return to your CCTV system’s web address.  Now you should receive a pop-up notification asking for permission to run an ActiveX control.
Finally, refresh the page.
You will see a screen with a light blue background.  Your browser should prompt you to run an ActiveX control.  Authorise your browser to do so, and when this screen appears, enter your username and password.


Mac OSX

Safari is the only browser on Mac OSX that consistently allows the necessary ActiveX controls for logging into a Provision-ISR system, although it is theoretically possible on Firefox too.
Instructions for Mac OSX will be made available soon.

Linux


There is currently no way to log into a Provision-ISR system via a browser on Linux, as the ActiveX controls necessary are not available for Linux.  Your best bet is to run Internet Explorer or Firefox in a Windows Virtualbox.  A theoretical possibility is to run Internet Explorer in Wine, but this has not been done to date with any success.

entry.title: Talking about The FAI Fix with Shane Dowd!
entry.content:
This morning at 06:30am Melbourne time, I got to speak to Shane Dowd of the FAI Fix.  The time flew by for me, and a video should make its way to YouTube soon.

In the meantime, here is a recap of what I had to say:

My name is Alexander, I'm 31 years old, and live in Melbourne, Australia.  By day I am a security technician and by evening I am a mobility monk in the .  I am also the author of The Odessia (www.theodessia.com) and blog at mobilitymonk.blogspot.com.
About a year ago, I started getting quite distressing pain in my right hip, which in retrospect was simply due to performing exercises without sufficient mobility or conditioning.  I have long since been interested in parkour, free-running, and tricking, and tried to build up slowly; however, even the fundamental kicks of tricking placed too much strain on my weak, tight groin -- hip flexors and adductors, mostly.  I want to the doctor, the doctor sent me for an X-ray, which "showed" I had a "cam" lesion on my right femoral head, and the irritation revealed by a subsequent MRI was used to support the diagnosis of femero-acetabular impingement.  The doctor recommended leading a more subdued life with less ambitious athletic goals and surgery to prevent arthritis.
My first attempt to fix the problem was to rest and get used to a sad life without the exciting physical pursuits I had dreamed of.  By that time I was already familiar with the work of Thomas Kurz and while attempting a wide deep squat, I gained an important insight.  If I depressed my right hip flexor with my thumb, I could squat without pain.  This showed me that the pain I felt had something to do with the muscles and connective tissue, not the bones.  It was a small insight, but it was very important.
I saw a link to Matt Hsu's channel, Upright Health, on an FAI sufferers' Facebook page.  Initially I was skeptical, but I decided to watch every video on his channel and critically examine what he had to say.  His argument made sense to me, and I also tried some of the exercises he demonstrated in his videos, with encouraging results.  I soon found out about the FAI Fix from there.  At any rate it would be at least six months, probably a year, before I would go into surgery, so why not give it a real go?
My experience of the FAI Fix has been of total success.  FAI is a thing of the past to me and I can't stress enough how important it is if you are thinking about surgery to properly try the FAI Fix.  The cost is a piddling fraction of surgery, and what have you got to lose?
I no longer feel any discomfort in my right hip and I have greater flexibility and mobility than ever before, not just the last couple of years.  The FAI Fix is really very simple: massage yourself, stretch, activate dormant muscles, and therein lies its genius.
My view of the FAI Fix is that it is actually a strength and flexibility training programme in disguise, and have built an entire method of training by synthesizing material from Thomas Kurz's tomes of sports science and the FAI Fix.  I am working on a manual that lays out this method, which I will publish soon.  By following this method, I have achieved enormous, transformative increases in flexibility and mobility in two months, far beyond my expectations.  I have never been flexible by any "stretch" of the imagination, but now gym members and even coaches approach me to ask for tips on flexibility.  I have no accreditation or formal training, but everyone can see that I'm doing something right.  As my flexibility gains translate into more eye-catching compound stretches, I expect interest to grow.
What has worked for me?  Really everything in the FAI Fix.  Where there is a choice of exercises, some work better than others, but they are all excellent and can be enhanced by adding weight or resistance.  An important fact of the stretching and tissue work is that it is an exercise in regulating anxiety, distress, and frustration.  Tissue work can be very painful, and if you fear the pain, it will hurt you.  Stretching is even more distressing in my experience -- or rather used to be -- because most places are populated by people who seem to stretch effortlessly and painlessly.  For me, it was humiliating and frustrating to be so limited and in so much pain, which of course only made it worse.  It was when the pain of the tissue work gave way to relief and the stretching actually worked, that I began to enjoy it.  It's still not easy, but it is satisfying where before it was distressing.
Words of advice and encouragement.  The FAI Fix will solve your FAI in the same way lifting weights will make you strong -- if you do it properly.  Remember this: if you have FAI it's because you DID NOT LISTEN to your body.  It's harsh but true, but it's definitely not too late.

Buy a cheap notebook and a pen, find a local gym where you don't feel self-conscious, and make time in your schedule to go there every day.  Don't say you'll do it at home, there's always a distraction there.  Don't get a personal trainer.  Spend time on your own, listen to your own body until you hear what it's been trying to tell you all these years.  I won't pretend to sound reasonable or conciliatory by saying "a couple times a week or whenever you can fit it in" -- NO, you only have one body and one life, and it's time to start living it to the full.

Best chapter yet. I love the heritage of the cats and the nicknames they have and Trouser's grandfather coming out of the stone with stories of the past had a mythical quality. I think I've got an idea of where this is going, I'll message you about it over the next week.

entry.title: New Chapters for January and February 2014
entry.content:
See the Published Chapters for details of the release schedule to follow.

First of all, many thanks to the people who have given me feedback and shared Odessa's first adventure, The Man in the Mountain. (Chapter II and Chapter III)

Especial thanks to my friends Timotej Kovačič and Ann M. Tedeschi-Davidson; Timotej has been invaluable behind the scenes and Ann's sketches of Odessa are a real delight.  Remember, these stories are released under a Creative Commons licence, so if you feel a surge of creativity when reading them, you already have permission to use this material!

Chapters IV to X: In the Ogres' Lair

Odessa's next adventure will take her to a dangerous, violent place, populated by enormous men and women.  However, by the end of her time there she will come to see that first impressions can be misleading.

Release Schedule

For the next seven weeks a new chapter shall be released every Friday afternoon. (Australian time)  This will take us from Friday the 17th of January 2014 until the 28th of February 2014.  By that time I hope to have a new batch of chapters lined up, but as I have to balance this project with work and studies, I can't make any promises yet.

Fear and Feedback

I am very new to writing with a view to publishing my work, and truth be told it is very frightening.  I am often beset by the fear that it's all clumsy rubbish; that no-one in his right mind would want to read it -- it's too long, too short, too predictable; it's contrived, unoriginal, uninteresting.
So I write and rewrite until there is nothing else I can do to make it better -- that's not to say I am satisfied with it, but I can only go so far under my own steam.

And this is where you can really help me.

I'd like to find an editor (anyone interested?) to review the stories before I publish them, but, either in addition to an editor or in place thereof, I'd like you, my readers to be my crowdsourced editors too.  Let me explain:

When I studied Shakespeare at university one of the most striking things that I learned about him was his method of writing; that is, he would change the script in response to feedback from the audience.  It is said that Shakespeare would watch the audience during the performance of his plays and take note of when they cheered and applauded and when they got bored or booed the players.  English audiences were very vocal back then.  If people liked certain dialogue or characters, Shakespeare worked more of that material into the play; if the audience didn't enjoy other parts, out they went.  This meant that the final version of the script could be radically different from when it was first performed; whether it had more artistic merit is debatable, but one thing was for sure: the audiences loved it, and I suspect that this is one reason for Shakespeare's enduring success.  He didn't have an elevated view of himself as an artiste; he had an incredible talent for telling stories, and had plenty of stories to tell -- or rather plagiarise by today's nauseating standards of copyright -- and did his utmost to write plays that communicated his ideas and kept people entertained.

What I mean by all this, to return to our little project here, is that I would love your feedback -- your encouragement of course, but especially your criticism.  What do you think of the characters?  What do you think of the descriptions?  Does the plot flow?  Does it stretch the suspension of disbelief?  What would you like to see more of?  What would you like to see less of?  How does reading this make you feel?

Wiki-style Editing

Following this invitation to shower me with your feedback, understand that these chapters are not set in stone.  If, months or years from now, you discover this novel and think of something I could do better, even in Chapter I, I will still be open to revising it.  That's the beauty of an online novel -- there is no final draft that I have to submit to a publisher, no deadline, no word limit.  Naturally, with the passage of time there will be less and less need or justification to alter the earlier chapters, but that doesn't mean it'll ever be out of the question.  I hope that as Odessa's adventure unfolds, we'll all get a better sense of who she is and how she'll interact with the characters she meets.

For now, I hope you enjoy her adventure in the ogres' lair.

Thank you! I'm very pleased you enjoy the descriptions. I have a lot of ideas and there are general themes I wish to explore, but I expect the story to take shape over the next few months. I'm getting a better sense of who Odessa is and what her function in the story will be, but I need to give it time. You'll get to see a lot more over the coming chapters.
congrats! ;-)

entry.title: Chapter IV: Trousers and Waistcoat
entry.content:
Trousers woke up from his nap and shambled off Odessa’s back.  He yawned and stretched. Odessa stirred in her sleep and turned on to her side.  Trousers helped himself to a quick nuzzle of her nape.  “Let’s go exploring,” he said to himself.

He made his way back to the piano and took the third path from the clearing.  It meandered through the garden, up the hills, and through a maze.  At the centre of the maze sat a life-sized statue of a cat on top of a brick wall.  As Trousers approached it, the grey stone skin melted away and the statue came to life.

“Welcome, young Trousers, we have much to talk about.”

Trousers sat before the venerable ginger tabby.  He had long white whiskers and the fur from his midriff to his shoulders was pitch black.

“Who are you?”

“I am Praetorius Pathfinder, but my daily name is Waistcoat.  Congratulations on receiving your summons.”

“Pathfinder Waistcoat?  As in Praetorius Pathfinder the First, who travelled with Gudrid the Viking across the frozen ocean to the New World?

“Yes, I am he.  After Gudrid settled in the New World, I received a second summons to accompany Lusita the Light Bringer.”

“Is it true that you guided Lusita through the Dark Valley of the giant black wolves?”

“We helped each other get through, it is probably fairer to say.”

"What did you find on the other side?"

"We found a gate in the rock that lead to a path through the Black Forest, past a clearing, to the bridge that leads to this garden in the clouds."

“Are the stories about the giant black wolves true?  How did you make it through?”

“Lusita’s willingness to step out of the shadows had more to do with our survival than we in the feline world give her credit for.  But that’s a story for another time."

"Will you ever return to your old family?"

"Not unless I receive a new summons, but I have already answered two.  And besides, many generations have passed since then.  I like to keep an eye on their descendants from here though.  I’m pleased to see that they haven’t gone in for this fashion of owning fluffy little dogs -- I can’t take those walking bathmats seriously."

"Don't you miss them?"

"Of course I do, but my place is here now.”

Trousers sighed.

“I wish I could be as brave as you.”

“Oh, Trousers,” he laughed, “you make it sound terribly grand.  To be honest I was often freezing and terrified; most of the time I had no idea whither to go or what to do!”

Trousers stared at his paws.  “Then you know how I feel.”

“Tell me more.”

Trousers scratched the ground in front of him and looked to the side.  “I’m not sure I am up to this task, Grandfather Waistcoat.”

“But, my dear cat, you have been summoned; and you’re a Pathfinder, no less.”

“Maybe there was a mistake, maybe I was supposed to remain a house cat.”

“A summons is never issued by mistake.”

“I know, that’s what Grandfather Buttons always said.”

“Ah yes, Praetorius the Tenth.  He had a very dapper set of black spots on his belly, but he had his moments.  Do you know that when he lead Peregrin the Pilgrim over The Crossings he nearly fell off the bridge?”

Trousers stared at his ancestor in amazement.  Waistcoat sauntered along the brick wall, pretending to nervously cross a bridge, looking back and veering off to the side until he allowed himself to drop off the edge.  Trousers burst out laughing and they both giggled like kittens.

“I thought I was the only one that could happen to!” Trousers exclaimed between fits of laughter.

“So did I,” Waistcoat replied mirthfully as he rolled on the ground and pretended to fall through the air.

Trousers laughed anew at Waistcoat’s antics and they both jumped up on and dropped off the fence, allowing themselves to fall over when they hit the ground.  After a final round of laughter, they both returned to their dignified sitting.  Waistcoat stretched and Trousers followed his lead.

“Don’t be ashamed to nuzzle Odessa and purr into her chest, or be stroked and held by her.  You two will be together for a long time.”

“I always thought that a cat is supposed to be more dignified than that.”

“Humbug!  Once you receive your summons, helping your traveller is supreme.  None of us had the foggiest idea what we were supposed to do, but if there is one thing I learned from my travels, and from watching those who went before you, it is that Odessa will need your love, counsel, and protection more than anything else.  There will be times, young Trousers, when you feel like nothing more than a carry-on kitty, but always remember that you were summoned for a reason.”

Praetorius Pathfinder the First returned to his original position, closed his eyes, and turned back into stone.  Trousers rubbed his head against the statue and he went on his way.

To return home and not look for another place

Yesh ra-ke-vet

It is time to to change

There's a train
Back to our neighbourhoods

entry.title: Plyometrics Injury Risk
entry.content:
Consider what this passage from "Corrective Exercise Solutions to Common Shoulder and Hip Dysfunction" by Evan Osar means:

"Ballistic- or plyometric-type training protocols have been shown to positively increase jumping height in participants of a six-week training program. However, there was a subsequent decrease in the strength of the soleus during the program, suggesting that this type of training preferentially recruits the global mobilizers over the local stabilizers – gastrocnemius versus the soleus in this case (Ng 1990)."

To me, this says that any plyometrics has to be balanced by functional training.

http://amzn.to/20pGX0g

entry.title: Published Chapters
entry.content:
Welcome!

The Odessia is an online fantasy adventure about a girl called Odessa and her companion, a cat called Praetorius Pathfinder XII, or Trousers for short.  Their journey begins when Odessa decides to cross Bridge #90 [Chapter I] to see The Man in the Mountain.  [Chapters II and III]

Please also have a look at the information about copyright and collaboration.

If you'd like to donate to this project:

 

Part I: Introduction

Chapter I: Our Sports Shall Be Seen  

Introducing Odessa and Trousers, the Crossings, and the mysterious green.

Part II: The Man in the Mountain

Chapter II: Climbing the Mountain

A talking mountain and a few friendly hands reaching out.

Chapter III: Meeting the Man

Odessa discovers the heart and soul of the mountain.

 

Part III: History, Music, Love

Chapter IV: The Piano in the Park (24th January 2014)

Chapter V: Timotheos (31st January 2014)

 

Part IV: In the Ogres' Lair

Odessa and Trousers enter a mysterious cave and find themselves caught between a rock and hard place.

Chapter IX: The Council for Creation and Improvement (28th February 2014)


Chapter X: Yugerkug's Pyrification (7th March February 2014)

Chapter XII: The Fall to Freedom (21st March 2014)

 

Part V: Money and Power

entry.title: Chapter XIV: The Fall to Freedom
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/lucianosignorelli/5288945940/sizes/l/
Tazagthrog stirred and sat up.  “What happened?”

Trousers looked up at Tazagthrog.  His skin glowed a gentle yellow in the moonlight and his amber eyes were now a delicate jasmine green.  “She reached out to you.  She wanted to share your pain.”

Tazagthrog’s face fell.

“I’m sorry,” he said.  “There was a lot of pain to share.”

He reached over and cupped Odessa’s body in his hands and held her over his lap.  He closed his eyes and filled the cave with a mournful groaning hum.  Trousers climbed up on to Tazagthrog and curled up on Odessa’s chest.

The melody of Tazagthrog's hums was broken by an angry shout.

“Tazagthrog! What are you doing! Have you gone completely out of your mind?”

He opened his eyes.  Turgolga emerged from the back of the cave and stared at him in astonishment.  Tazagthrog put Odessa and Trousers down and stood up to face her.  She gasped when she saw his exposed body, his bulging muscles, his electric blue scars, his jasmine green eyes.

“Tazagthrog, look at you!  Where are your scales?  Who did this to you?  You look ridiculous!  How are we supposed to go back home with you looking like this?  What will the Council think?”

Tazagthrog smiled and met her gaze.  Her slanted yellow eyes widened and her nostrils flared at the insult. 

Tazagthrog replied calmly, “Do  you remember that time in the square, Turgolga?  That time when I stepped into your space?”

She hesitated.  “All those years ago?  Yes, you nearly crashed into me; it was only sheer luck that I missed your ears when I hit you.  What’s that got to do with this?”

“I don’t think you wanted to hit my ears.”

She paused.  “Maybe I didn’t, so what then?  What are we going to do with you?  How could you do this to me?  Who ever heard of an ogre without scales?  And look at your eyes!  They’re like a  ogreson’s!  Did she do this to you?  I knew I should have squashed her the moment I saw her!”

Turgolga advanced on Odessa and Trousers, but Tazagthrog stepped in front of them.  “No, Turgolga, let them be.”

“What did you just say to me?”

Tazagthrog brought himself face to face with her.  “Leave them alone,” he said with gentle firmness.  “I’ll take them to the Outside: they can continue their journey from there.”

Turgolga’s hand struck his ear with especial venom.  He absorbed the blow as if he were made of rock.  Then, a growling hiss emanated from his throat as he reared up like a king cobra.  Turgolga raised her hand to strike him again.  As her open hand swung around, a much larger, more powerful hand lashed out at her cheek; she crashed to the ground and when she looked up, Tazagthrog’s scars danced on his heaving chest.

“How dare you?” She hissed.  “How dare you strike an ogress?”

“How dare you strike an ogre?” He replied.

Turgolga’s mouth moved but no words came out.  She looked at Odessa, who lay at the edge of the cave and Trousers who stood guard over her, his hazel eyes shining defiantly in the moonlight.

“It’s all because of her!” Turgolga shouted. “She’s worked some kind of magic on you.  You’re not the real Tazagthrog -- yes, that’s it -- you’ve been cursed by her, she’s robbed you of your scales!”

Turgolga heaved herself up and disappeared into the cave screaming and shouting for help.  Yugherkug emerged from the shadows.

“Father! What happened to you?  Where are your scales?”

“I'm free, Yugherkug.”

“How can that be?”

“I have learned what it means to allow someone to reach out to you.”

“How do you do that?  I want to get rid of my scales too.”

“Go to the place I told you about.  Learn to make more sketches, I left parchment and ink, drink and food for you, and then start journeying into the Great Beyond.”

“What lies in the Great Beyond?”

“I don't know, but you need to meet someone like Odessa, who can teach you the things we never learn here.”

“Can't you come with me?  I don't want to go alone.”

“It's too late for me, the others will be here soon and they will never let me leave now.”

Tazagthrog smiled at Yugherkug and extended his arms to him.  Yugherkug stepped forward; Tazagthrog hesitated slightly and then wrapped his arms around Yugherkug, who stiffened momentarily and then relaxed in his father's embrace.

“I'm sorry, Yugherkug.”

“Sorry for what?”

“I'm sorry I didn't stop your Cleansing.”

“If you had tried, you would have had to face the Council.”

“I know, but I still should have tried.”

They held each other silently.

“Goodbye, my son.”

“Goodbye, my father.”

I love you, my son.”

“What does 'love' mean, father?”

“It means being softer and tougher than ever before.  It means sharing something that no-one else can have, but it also means sometimes giving it up so that someone else can go on.”

“What are you going to give up for me?”

Turgolga returned with a crowd of astonished ogres and ogresses; Yugherkug faded back into the shadows as they approached.  Tazagthrog picked up Odessa and Trousers and held them to his chest.  When Yamizert pushed through the crowd she gasped.  She ran to her mother and clutched her hand.  Yugherkug stood in the shadows, entranced by his father’s pulsating scars and ran his hand along his own chest.

“Look at what that little monster did to my ogreman!” Turgolga declared.  “I invited her into my home, kept her as a pet, made sure that no ogre would lay his hands on her, and see how she has repaid me!”

The crowd murmured in astonishment:

- “Where are his scales?”
- “Are those the scars from his Cleansing?”
- “I’ve never seen an ogre without scales before.”
- “He’ll have to have another Cleansing.”
- “We can’t have an ogre walking around town without scales.”

“Tazagthrog has gone mad,” Turgolga declaimed.  “When I came up here he was in frenzied state; I tried to calm him, but he – he hit me!”

The crowd gasped

“It was all I could do to defend myself, luckily I escaped before he finished me off.  Look, look at these wounds!”

The crowd murmured excitedly as Turgolga pointed to the mild bruising on her face.

- “An ogre hitting an ogress?”
- “On purpose?”
- “Poor Tazagthrog has lost it.”
- “We need to set up the Cleansing immediately.”

“Tazagthrog,” Turgolga announced, “give me my pets back.  We need to dispose of these wicked creatures and prepare you for a Cleansing.  You’ve done a terrible thing, an unforgivable thing, but I can find it in my heart to forgive you if you grovel enough.”

The crowd advanced towards him.

“You don’t understand, Turgolga,” he replied.  “I’m not coming back.”

The crowd drew closer.

“Goodbye, Turgolga.  I always loved you.”

Tazagthrog cocooned Odessa and Trousers in his arms, closed his eyes, and allowed himself to fall backwards off the edge.

Tazagthrog's body glowed like a falling star as they made their long descent to the bottom of the canyon.  The night air rushed around him, but Odessa and Trousers were shielded from the wind.  As they fell, they were accompanied by the reflection of cats-eyes in the rock; time slowed down; it seemed they were in limbo.  Tazagthrog's hums vibrated through Trousers and Odessa; her eyes began to open.  The falling star completed its journey and found its resting place.  A mighty thud of bone and flesh on rock echoed around the canyon, but Odessa and Trousers were cushioned by his underbelly.  Tazagthrog's hands fell limply to his sides and he stared up into the sky.  His breathing was laboured.

Odessa woke up and looked around.  “Where are we?  What happened?”

“Turgolga found us.  She wanted to do away with us, but Tazagthrog saved us.  We’re at the bottom of the canyon.”

“How did we get down here?”

“Tazagthrog jumped, but he protected us from the fall.”

Odessa looked up at the cave far, far in the distance.

“Tazagthrog, are you alright?”

He tried to get up, but succeeded only in folding his hands on his chest.

“Oh, Tazagthrog, why did you do this to yourself to save us?  I’m so sorry I got you into all this trouble!”

He looked at her with a softness in his eyes.  His breathing became more laboured and the scars began to dim.

“No, Odessa, before I met you, I was nothing more than an ogre.  No-one ever reaches out to an ogre, no-one ever cares.  All my life I longed to be loved, but ogresses don’t allow themselves to love -- only to fear, only to hate -- and ogres aren’t allowed to be soft.  We live our whole lives in pain; we take it out on each other, on the animals we kill, on the rocks that we smash; but nothing has ever taken the pain away.”

“But all I did was open my heart to you, Tazagthrog.  Why can’t the ogresses do the same?”

“I don’t know.  Everyone says that after my Cleansing I was changed; but I think it was Turgolga who really changed.  I healed from the knife and the fire, but she was the one that delivered the knife and ignited the fire.  On the inside I’ve always been Tazagthrog the Gentle (that’s what they used to say to make fun of me), but something delicate inside Turgolga was burned away that day.  It took me years to understand this; and when I did, there was nothing anyone could do about it.”

He coughed painfully.

“I’m sorry, Tazagthrog, I’m so sorry for all of this.”

“Don’t apologise.  Without you, I would have never had the courage to tell Yugherkug about my sketches.  Now he knows what it means to be held and loved, and he shall see the things I never had the words to say.  One day, Yugherkug will find a way to tell other ogres what I never could.  You've given us a great gift, Odessa, the gift of a kind touch.  I am happy now, happier than I ever could have been...”

Tazagthrog closed his eyes with his hands on his heart.  A single large tear trickled down his cheek and crystallised into a pearl coloured orb that shone with a fading blue light, which rolled into Odessa’s hands.  The light of his scars faded completely.  He smiled as his breathing slowed and finally stopped.

Odessa laid her hand affectionately on Tazagthrog’s cheek, put the pearl into her backpack, and followed Trousers into the canyon.  After some time the canyon gave way to a ravine; the ravine to a beach; at the beach was a pier; at the end of the pier, Bridge #91 stretched out over the sea.

entry.title: Response to Matt Hsu from Upright Health
Defining the Problem and Defining Success
entry.content:
The Problems

Pain, Discomfort, Hypertension, Inactivity

Sumo squat pain

When I try to perform a sumo squat, I get pain in the muscle directly over my right hip.

Right hamstring

My right hamstring is perennially tight.

Right gluteal muscles

When I perform the "superman", my right gluteal muscles do not activate and the load of lifting my right leg and holding it up is taken over by my right lower back and right hamstring.

Right calf muscles

Both sets of calf muscles are probably quite tight, but if I am dehydrated and sleep deprived, my right calf muscle may spasm in the night, and remain tender for the following days unless treated.

Right shoulder

My right shoulder often gets tight and is especially uncomfortable when I am driving.

Neck

I have a lot of tension in my neck, resulting in numerous clicks through the vertebrae if I rotate my neck sharply to the right or left.  (More often to the right)

Trapezoid Muscles

Quite strong and perennially tight.  I have a habit of shrugging in the Gallic manner and need to remind myself to relax those muscles.

Scapulae

My scapulae are very inactive and seem to be engaged only when I consciously do so.

Restricted Range of Motion

Rounded back when sitting on the floor

Sitting on the floor with my legs crossed.
Sitting on the floor with my legs straight out.

Rounded back and collapsed frame when sitting in a chair

Rounded back and limited internal hip rotation when sitting in "executive" pose

Lordosis when standing and dancing, but not when jogging or running*

Right calf gets tight and tends to spasm if I'm dehydrated

Hip dysplacia/tension

When I try to internally rotate my hip, the same muscle that I feel pain in during the sumo squat remains tense and sore.

My Goals

1. Deep sumo squat with my feet double the width of my shoulders.


Thomas Kurz in his fifties, showing how it's done.

2. Side Splits

Thomas Kurz in his fifties, showing how it's done.

3. Front Splits, both sides

Thomas Kurz in his thirties, demonstrating front splits

 4. Back Bridge, full extension of arms and legs



5. Sitting comfortably with my legs crossed, straight back

6. Sitting comfortably in the lotus position

7. Sitting comfortably with my legs extended and back
straight

8. Touch the floor with the palms of my hands, straight legs

9. Stand comfortably without lordosis

10. Achieve body position for handstand

11. Pancake with legs splayed at least 90 degrees

12. Pancake with splits

13. Pancake with legs straight out

entry.title: Ishay Ribo - Watching Over Us Through The Window (Mash-gi-yaḥ min ha-ḥa-lon-ot)
entry.content:
משגיח מן החלונות / Mash-gi-yaḥ min ha-ḥa-lon-ot

אף פעם לא תקצר ידו  כי לעולם חסדו
Af pa-am lo tik-tzar ya-do
Ki le-olam ḥas-do

אי אפשר לתאר עוצמתו, לא כוחו ואהבתו
Iy ef-shar le-ta-er otz-ma-to
Lo ko-ḥo ve-a-ha-va-to

-איה מקום כבודו, ואין קץ ליופיו והודו
E-ye me-kom ke-vo-do,
ve-eyn ketz le-yof-yo ve-ho-do

אם נבקש ודאי נוכל למוצאו

משגיח מן החלונות,מגשים את כל החלומות

mag-shim et kol ha-ḥa-lo-mot

וגם כשהוא מסתיר פנים,עודו מציץ מין החרכים
Ve-gam ksh-hu mas-tir pa-nim,
o-do me-tzitz min ha-ḥa-ra-kim

והוא יפן ברחמיו לבניו, ובלעדיו מי יהיה לנו אב
Ve-hu yi-fen be-ra-ḥa-mav le-ba-nav
U-bi-la-dav mi yi-ye la-nu av

עוד ישוב  ויגאלנו שנית,ולצרותינו ישים קץ אחרית
Od ya-shuv ve-yig-a-lei-nu she-nit,
U-le-tza-ro-tei-nu ya-sim ketz a-ḥa-rit

-איה מקום כבודו, ואין קץ ליופיו והודו
E-ye me-kom ke-vo-do,
ve-eyn ketz le-yof-yo ve-ho-do
