Im ne-va-kesh va-da-iy nu-ḥal le-mo-tzo

entry.title: New Splits Flexibility Milestone: Ten Inches!
entry.content:
I've been working towards 10 inches off the ground for many weeks, and I was quite surprised to feel the bench between my thighs, after not getting there so many times.

I understand it's a little more than ten inches, strictly speaking, because my groin is a little higher (for reasons of simple geometry), but making contact with the bench step at this height had eluded me for a very long time, so I'll enjoy this small success.



I have been training the weighted wide sumo squat for about two months, which got me down to ten inches at a very wide squat (seven-step squat according to the Thomas Kurz method), but when I tried to translate that to straight-leg splits, I could only come to rest on the bench step at twelve inches off the ground.  (Five blocks plus the bench)



Also, I couldn't get any farther down with weighted sumo squats: if I tried, I compromised my straight foot positioning (i.e. I turned my feet out) in order to maintain external rotation of my femurs.  I suspect this limitation was simply due to having reached the limits of the range permitted by my inner thigh muscles.



I predict that once I am comfortable at ten inches with straight legs, I'll be able to go further with weighted sumo squats -- possibly to eight inches, i.e. three steps plus the bench.

entry.title: Chapter VI: The Cave in the Canyon
entry.content:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/kateure1309/6455246227/sizes/l/

Bridge #135 took Odessa and Praetorius Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) down from the sky into the depths of a grand canyon.  They arrived at the opening of a cave high up in the wall of the sheer cliff.

As they stepped off, the final slat exploded in a rush and the rest of the bridge disintegrated in the morning sunlight.

Odessa’s shadow stretched into the cave, but beyond the entrance it fell into darkness.

Odessa pulled out of her bag a pearl-coloured orb that fit comfortably in the palm of her hand.  It had been a birthday present from a strange old man who joined her family on their travels for a while.  When they set up their stalls and street performances, he walked around town chatting with people and somehow always convinced them to buy something or see a show.  He never rushed, yet he always got everything done.  He wore flowing clothes and had a long white beard; he was the only adult Odessa had met that could speak with her animals. 

Any adult can talk with animals, but somewhere along the way most adults forget how to listen, first to animals, then to children, then to each other, and finally to themselves.  Animals worked this out a long time ago, which is why dogs make lots of gestures and noises, and cats bring us dead birds; they find it hard to see how we adults can take care of ourselves when we have forgotten how to listen to our own bodies.

On Odessa’s seventeenth birthday, the old man sat down with her and placed the orb in her hand.  “As long as you look with an open heart and think kind thoughts, the light of this orb will show you the way,” he said.  It now floated from the palm of her hand and hovered like a little lantern over her head; they left the sun-lit mouth of the cave and examined their surroundings in the light of the orb’s gentle white glow.

Trousers sniffed the air suspiciously.  “I don’t like the smell of this place,” he said.

The cave narrowed to a tall, broad tunnel.  There were animal bones strewn on the floor and and brown smears on the walls.  They reached a fork in the tunnel; they stood there, wondering which way to go, when they heard lumbering footsteps and the sound of bodies dragging on the ground coming from the tunnel to the right.
They stepped into the tunnel to the left and looked back into the main tunnel.  The outline of a pair of giants came into view.  One dragged a collection of gargantuan sheep, goats, and cows behind him on a rope; the other carried a bundle of firewood under his arm.

“Let’s have a one of these as a snack at the Old Entrance.”  The first giant said in a deep, slow, almost childlike voice.
“Good idea, I’ bin bashin’ rock all through the night and I’m starvin’,” replied his friend, in a slightly less deep, but equally uninflected tone.
“You ain’t starvin’, you fa’ oaf, you’re a greedy troll”
“Who you callin’ a troll, you goblin!”

And the two giants continued walking, exchanging clumsy insults and pushing each other into the wall, which sent vibrations through the rock.

“Trousers, what were those men?  I’ve never seen anyone so big in my life!”

“We are in the ogres’ lair.  My grandfather, Praetorius Pathfinder X (known to his friends as Buttons for the dots on his belly) passed through here once.  He said the ogres are very stupid, but if they get a hold of you, they think it good sport to use you as a plaything -- and they play very rough indeed.  He also said to beware of -- watch out!”

And before Odessa could turn around, a pair of huge hands reached out of the shadows, grabbed her by the waist and lifted her high into the air.  Odessa’s vision was filled by a pair of huge yellow eyes and big yellow teeth.  Trousers scampered back into the entrance tunnel and watched helplessly as the ogress held Odessa aloft like a doll.

“You’re an ugly little creature,” the ogress said.  “You’re the boniest, skinniest thing I’ve seen.”  The ogress’s breath hit Odessa’s face like a sulfurous tropical wind; Odessa gagged and coughed as she tried to reply.  The ogress put Odessa back down and prodded her, sending her flying back into the entrance tunnel.  Odessa allowed her body to be carried by the force of the blow and when her feet made contact with the ground she dissipated the momentum with an agile safety roll back over her shoulder.

“I’m sorry!” the ogress exclaimed, “I didn’t mean to hurt you.  You’re not broken, are you?”

“That’s alright,” Odessa replied, dusting herself off.  “I’m used to being thrown around, it’s part of the act that I used to perform in.”

“You were in a show?  Could you show me more of your act?”

“I’d be happy to, but who were those two ogres who came by?”

“They were a couple of rock workers; I saw them come up here and wanted to see what they were up to.  Now come back here before they grab you and decide to have you as a snack.”

The ogress wore a skirt and a top made of animal skin; she had vast legs like gelatinous tree trunks and a pot belly that her top barely concealed.  Her skin was the colour of mustard and her limbs were roadmapped with protruding veins.  She had wiry hair that went just past her ears.  Having got over her astonishment at her sheer size and strangeness, Odessa examined the ogress’s face more appreciatively.  Her face had a couple of moles and what looked like a wart on the tip of her nose; her teeth, though large and yellow, were quite straight.  Her big flat nose seemed about right for her round face, and her pointy ears stuck out of her hair in a way that, if nothing else, suited her features.  Her narrow eyes examined Odessa intelligently.

“What are you, little things?” The ogress asked.

“My name is Odessa.  I’m a girl, or a woman I suppose.  What’s your name?”

“I am Turgolga, chieftain of the Roundbelly clan.”

“That sounds rather important.”

“Yes, we’re one of the leadings clans.  I’m also the head of the Council for Improvement and Creation,” Turgolga replied proudly.  “What’s that fuzzy thing you’ve got there?”

“His name is Trousers.  He’s a cat.”

“Praetorius Pathfinder, actually, but you may call me Trousers if you like.”

“It looks like something that one of our animals might cough up.  Come to think of it, one of the old ogresses told me she had seen a furball like that once.  She had never seen anything move so fast -- she chased it, but it escaped to the Outside, and of course the ogres there lost track of it within minutes.  You can’t rely on them to get anything right.  I always wondered what it looked like.  Quite unimpressive, I’ll say; and very skinny.  He’d barely be worth cooking by the looks of it.”

Odessa picked up Trousers and held him protectively.

“What are you doing here?” the Ogress asked.

“We’re travellers; we came here on a white bridge.  We need to find another one to continue our journey.”

“We’ve never had a traveller arrive by the Old Entrance.  There was a bridge that lead here once, but that was generations ago.”  Turgolga strode towards Odessa.  Odessa thought of running away, but she didn’t fancy her chances of making it past Turgolga’s large, powerful hands or faring any better with the ogres at the Old Entrance.  Turgolga picked Odessa up again and sniffed her suspiciously. “I’m not sure what magic brought you here, but you seem harmless enough.”  She put Odessa back down and put her hands on her enormous hips.

“Tell me, what’s the difference between a girl and a woman?”

“It’s hard to say,” Odessa began, “but some people would say that when you’re a woman you’re too soft and delicate to run around and climb trees and wrestle with boys and build things and break things, but when you’re a girl you’re tough enough to do all those things.”

“So does that mean you start as a woman and then grow into a girl?”

“Not exactly,” Odessa replied.  “It’s usually the other way around.”

“How do you start tough and become soft?  I’ve never heard of such a thing.”

Odessa was about to reply that she herself was still trying to work it out, when the heavy footsteps of the returning ogres interrupted them.

“Quick, come with me,” Turgolga whispered, “I’ll take you home; you’ll be safe there.  And besides, I’d love to show you to the Council.”

“Will they eat us?”

“Not unless we vote unanimously to do so,” Turgolga replied without a hint of sarcasm, “and besides they’ll probably enjoy your performance -- we always enjoy a new performance.  Also, I’d like to hear more about why your little people get soft when they grow up.”

As Turgolga set off, Odessa took a ball of bright string from her bag and let it trail out behind her.  They followed Turgolga into a dizzying labyrinth of tunnels, sometimes turning left, sometimes turning right, sometimes going straight ahead.  The walls of the tunnels were illuminated at regular intervals with crafted torches and decorated with delicate tribal patterns and artwork.

“These tunnels are incredible,” Odessa whispered.  “Who created all this?”

“We did, of course.”

“You mean the ogres?”

Turgolga snorted with laughter.  “What? No! Ogres can’t create anything -- except for some primitive patterns, I suppose.  Everything here was created by the ogresses.”

Odessa was confused.  “Those ogres who walked by looked enormously strong.  Why didn’t they help you?”

Turgolga made a guttural snort . “Clearly, you can’t tell the difference between creating and making.  The ogres did the stupid work of digging and carving and hewing and carrying, but you need ogresses to create the idea.  If you left an ogre to his own devices he’d simply bash his head against the rock, or rather bash another ogre’s head against the rock.  If it weren’t for the ogresses to keep the ogres in check, we’d all be huddled on the Entrance, shivering in the wind.”

“I think I understand,” Odessa replied.  “It must be difficult to live with ogres if they’re as rough and thick as that.  I guess they’re a bit like some boys where I come from.”

“We do our best to keep them in check,” Turgolga sighed, “But life for an ogress was never meant to be easy.”


The Odessia, a fantasy novel by Alexander J Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://www.theodessia.com.

entry.title: How To Reset Curly Hair with Handfuls of Water
entry.content:
If you don't have curly hair, you probably don't understand that having reasonably neat hair for a curly-haired person is like running through a muddy football field while wearing an all-white zoot suit.  If you start the day without frizz, you're lucky; if you get to the end of the day without frizz, you thank you lucky stars.
As we curly hairs know, the only way to get frizzy hair back under control is to get it wet -- but what happens if you can't jump in the shower and don't have a bottle to spray your hair with?

Let's say you're out and about -- maybe you had a rough day at work and haven't had a chance to get back home -- and you're having a bad hair day.  You know what, let's make it a really bad hair day.  Actually, let's make it a ridiculously bad hair day.

In this guide, I will show you a simple way to reset your hair that you can use when you can't get in the shower -- be it at a friend's place or in a public rest-room.

The first thing to understand is that if you want to reset the curls all the way down, you don't have to wet all your hair.  This might sound counter-intuitive, but think of it like this.  If you wet your scalp, the hair on the top of your head will absorb the water.  However, if you keep on adding water to the top of your head, eventually the hair on your scalp will become saturated, and the excess water will travel down the hair strands and progressively saturate the length of your hair.

The advantage of wetting your hair in this way is two-fold:
Firstly, you avoid the mess of washing your hair with a stream of water.  You don't need a shower head or even a place to shower, because very little water will go anywhere.  If you have a towel, it's not a bad idea, but at worst you can just take your shirt off.
Secondly, this is actually a much better way of resetting your curls than blasting your hair with water because this method allows the small amounts of excess water to nourish your hair by carrying the natural oils from your scalp gently down your hair strands.  People with straight hair achieve this by brushing or combing their hair -- that's why it looks shiny after being brushed.  You could brush curly hair, but only if you want to look like a clown.

So keep on dabbing the top of your head with handfuls of water until it is saturated, and then use your hands to squeeze the excess water into the ends of your hair.  Eventually your hair will be fully saturated and you will already be able to separate it into long curls.  If you follow this process gently and patiently, there will be little water on the floor or even the sink and you'll be able to put your shirt back on with minimal fuss.
Leave your hair loose and allow it a little time to dry.

Before you know it, you'll have perfectly reset curls and be ready to face the rest of your day, or night, or morning.

You must do what you feel is the right course for you. I wish you all the best and I look forward to the further incarnations of the Odessia. Please keep me posted on all updates with the project. Much success and happiness, Alex.

entry.title: Freight Calculator Prototype: LAMP Stack on an EC2 written in PHP
entry.content:
Here is a crude, but illustrative beginning of an application I'm working on:

http://52.62.159.146/form.html
It is hosted on an Amazon EC2 instance that I created, running Ubuntu 16.04 with Apache2, MySQL 5.7, and PHP7.
I can SFTP using FileZilla and I have set a BASH script on all my computers to log into it automatically
An Ubuntu EC2 instance is 14.04 by default, but I did a full system upgrade over SSH. (It was fun)
Obviously, I'm doing everything on the command line, and for editing the files I'm using Nano -- it's not Vim or Emacs, but it's good enough for me.
The inspiration for this project comes straight from my job.
The working "app" is a Google sheet that I built to automate the calculation of freight so that the sales staff wouldn't pester me to measure and weigh products and look up shipping rates
I obtained all the shipping rates from our current courier and have been measuring and weighing the products methodically
At this point, 9/10 shipping estimates are fully automated and I can get on with other tasks, so the task is to replicate the full functionality of the spreadsheet in a website, hosted on an EC2 instance, running a full LAMP stack, written in PHP that creates records and returns shipping estimates by interacting with a MySQL database
The Google sheet works just fine for the people in the office, but I hope to use this web application to showcase my skills and other desirable traits in a development role
Obviously, it's not very pretty, but if you understand how these things work (I assume you do), then you'll understand how much one needs to learn in order to get to this point.

entry.title: Ishay Ribo: Here Come the Days (Hineh Yamim Ba'im)
entry.content:
פזיז מעשים בהול תנועות
אין עוד פנאי להמתין ולא זמן לחכות
ירידת הדורות
כנראה הסיבה לעליית התורות בקופה הראשית
שמענו לפידים וראינו את הקולות
את ההר עשן למען ה׳ איך עוד הלב הזה ישן
בתור לקופה הראשית

Paziz ma'asim behul tnu'ot
Ein od pnai le-hamtin ve-lo zman le-chakot
Yeridat ha-dorot
Kanireh ha-sibah le-aliyat ha-torah ba-kupah ha-rashiyt
Shamanu lapidim ve-ra'iynu et ha-kolot
Et ha-har ashen le-ma'an Ha-Shem ein od ha-lev ha-zeh yashen
Ba-tor la-kupah ha-rashiyt

ערפילי טהר
לא בחיל ולא בכח
רק בשם ומלכות
כשזה יבוא זה יבוא זה יבוא
בלי מקום לטעות

Arpiyley tohar
Lo be-chayil ve-lo be-ko'ach
Rak be-shem u-malchut
K-sh-zeh yavo zeh yavo zeh yavo
Bliy makom le-ta'ut

הנה ימים באים נאום ה׳ אלוקים
לא רעב ללחם
לא צמא למים

Hineh yamim ba'im
Ne'um Ha-Shem (H') Elokiym
Lo ra'av la-lechem
Lo tzama la-mayim

ערל שפתיים נבוב לוחות
אם ללמד עלינו זכות
זה על הרצון לשנות
להסיר מסכות
זמן לגילוי הפנים

Aral sfatayim nevuv luchot
Im le-lamed aleinu zchut
Zeh al ha-ratzon le-shanot
Le-hasir masechot
Zman le-giyluiy ha-paniym

לא רעב ללחם לא צמא למים
רק דיבורים של אמת המשביעים את הלב
ירידת הדורות
כנראה הסיבה לעליית התורות בספריה הראשית

Lo ra'av la-lechem, lo tzama la-mayim
Rak diyburiym shel emet ha-masbiy'iym et ha-lev
Yeridat ha-dorot
Kanireh ha-sibah le-aliyat ha-torah ba-sifriyah ha-rashiyt

entry.title: Foot Pain Cured with a Baseball
entry.content:
More portable than a masseur!
Today while walking around at work, I had sharp pain in the ball of my foot around the third and fourth toes with almost every step I took on my left foot.
I consulted my Egoscue book, 'Pain Free' and looked up a couple of forums, where I saw mention of postural alignment.

I retrieved my handy baseball from my bag, took off my shoes, and stood with my left foot on the baseball, with my weight distributed slightly more to my left.

After about a minute of pain, I began to feel the muscles in my upper left thigh and upper left calf twitching and releasing.  I felt similar echoes in my left hip flexors.  After a few minutes, I tried walking again, and the PAIN WAS GONE.

All this was happening while I continued working on a machine at my work bench.

No massage, no physiotherapist, no acupuncture: just a baseball.

entry.title: Chapter X: The Council
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/geralds_1311/5957218085/sizes/l
Odessa’s scribbling was interrupted by a hubbub outside the front entrance.  Turgolga was followed into the front room by a procession of high ranking ogresses who together constituted the Council for Creation and Improvement (known generally as the Council), which oversaw all matters of chief importance in the city of Ogressia.  The chieftanship of the Council rotated between the hostesses of each meeting; from now until the next monthly meeting, Turgolga would sit at the head of the table.
All the ogresses adorned their corpulent frames with elaborate necklaces, beads, and bracelets; they stood at attention around the great stone table facing Turgolga, who began:

“Esteemed members of the Council for Creation and Improvement, I call today’s meeting to order.  Let us begin with a call of present members:
“Thugherga?” – “Bellowblast!”
“Ragudda?” – “Blackheart!”
“Gaghregga?” – “Thunderstone!”
“Kuzrobbina?” – “Oxenrider!”
“Serarka?” – “Cannonfist!”
“Marghbartha?” – “Shadowback!”

“And I, Turgolga Roundbelly, chieftan of the Council for this moonspan, am of course present.  Before we begin, I have something to show the Council.  Odessa!”

Odessa approached the table.  The ogresses stared in astonishment.

–- “My goodness! What is the bizarre little creature?”
–- “It looks like a baby hobgoblin.”
–- “Uglier, I should say.”
–- “Is it dirty?”
–- “It doesn’t look dirty.”
–- “Turgolga wouldn't bring a dirty creature into her home.”
–- “Of course not.”
–- “Still, it looks nasty.”
–- “And skinny too.”
–- “Yes, eerily skinny.”
–- “Where did it come from?”

Turgolga motioned for the Council to let her speak.

“This creature is called a ‘woman’ and I found her near the Old Entrance.”

“The Old Entrance?”
“How did she get there?”
“It must have been magic!”
“Don’t touch her, she might give you scales!”

“She is harmless to touch, dear Council members.  She has trained as a performer: isn’t that right, Odessa?”

“Yes, Turgolga.”

–- “Ooh, a performer!”
–- “We love a good performance.”
–- “What did you think of last night’s drum dance?”
–- “The young ogresses are getting better, but ogresses these days are far too skinny.”
–- “That’s what they said about us before we came of age.”
–- “I know, but they can’t move if they don’t have anything to move with.”
–- “Too true”
–- “It's almost as if they're worried about looking good for the ogresons.”
–- “Ha! Don't be ridiculous!”
–- “You always say the most outrageous things, Serarka.”
–- “Not as outrageous as some of the outfits those emaciated ogresses were wearing last night, Kuzrobbina.”
–- “I thought they were rather weak, if you ask me.”

“Council members, please! Let us sit down and let our little visitor perform for us.”

The ogresses sat down heavily around the table.  Turgolga motioned for Odessa to climb up and put on a show.  Odessa hopped up nervously on to the table and looked around.  Even though Odessa stood comfortably above her spectators, she felt herself to be easily within their grasp.

She faced Turgolga and raised her arms out to her sides.  She clapped a slow steady beat with her hands and indicated that the spectators should follow suit.  The ogresses clapped along with her: “clap (two-three-four), clap (two-three-four), clap (two-three-four)...”
Odessa bent backwards into a bridge, kicked her legs up, and settled into a handstand.  The ogresses sighed appreciatively and continued their rhythmic clapping.  She walked rhythmically along the table on her hands, straddled her legs, and lowered her legs down to a seated straddle.  She closed her legs, rolled backwards into a candle, and popped up into a handstand, and came back on to her feet.  She stepped to the beat of the claps, twirling her hands and sweeping her upper body around.
She did a neat cartwheel off her left foot, then a neat cartwheel back off her right; a one-handed cartwheel, then another the other way; an aerial cartwheel (hands up neatly at the end), and then an aerial cartwheel the other way; a butterfly kick one way and then the other, and finally a butterfly twist, out of which she went into a spot turn, and corkscrewed down until she ended with her legs crossed facing Turgolga.

“Marvellous! Marvellous!” Turgolga exclaimed.  The rest of the ogresses clapped enthusiastically.

–- “What a clever little creature!”
–- “I’m too dignified to move like that these days, but I could do that in my day.”
–- “Oh yes, I too, before I chose my ogreman.”
–- “Yes, you can’t do anything with an ogreman around.”
–- “They never get anything right.”
–- “Nothing at all.”

Odessa took a bow and hopped off the table.

“Thank you, Odessa,” Turgolga announced, “now let us get down to business…”

Tazagthrog appeared at the doorway, his head bowed, his hands placed over each other at the height of his bellybutton.  Turgolga motioned impatiently for him to come in and he quietly slipped past them into the kitchen.  “Always so noisy and slow, my ogreman Tazagthrog” Turgolga said and the others hummed in agreement.  “I don’t know why I granted him my presence, but I suppose he could be worse.  He’s almost not too stupid sometimes.”

“He’s very lucky to be with you, Turgolga.”
“I know, Thugherga, but he makes me feel so unappreciated sometimes.”
“That’s how they are; try as you might, you can’t change them; you can only do your best to keep them in line.”

A few minutes later, Tazagthrog appeared with a titanic platter of cooked meat and vegetables, and a plate so small that it barely covered the palm of his hand.  He placed the platter on the table, and surreptitiously deposited a tiny plate (by ogre standards) in front of Odessa before whisking out.  The ogresses pounced on the platter and devoured its contents, shovelling great handfuls of meat and vegetables into their mouths with much grunting and burping and smacking of lips.  They washed their food with cupfuls of ogre wine and beer, and within a short while the entire platter had been picked clean.  Odessa could barely move after eating her portion of meat and vegetables  The ogresses sat back, not entirely satiated, and Turgola shouted to the entrance, “Tazagthrog, we need to talk!”

Tazagthrog appeared at the doorway; Turgolga got up clumsily and walked into the kitchen.  Tazagthrog followed her in there and sounds of hitting and angry whispers emerged through the doorway: “Embarrass me in front of my guests… tiny portion… useless… pathetic… I don’t know why… well cook some more… you’ll just have to try harder next time…”

Turgolga re-emerged from the kitchen and sat down at the table.  “I am terribly sorry for his incompetence.  He never gets it right.  I created the meal for him, but, yet again, he couldn’t make it properly.  Sometimes I think I should just make it myself.”

– “Don’t say that, Turgolga!”
– “You’re so patient with him.”
– “I don’t have such restraint with my Teggrut!”
– “Come now, it was a respectable appetiser.”

Mollified by the encouragement of her friends and the sight of their swollen bellies, Turgolga’s mood lightened and she commenced the meeting of the Council.

For the rest of the day, the Council for Creation and Improvement discussed such matters as which ogreman was the most incompetent, whether beer or wine went best with ham, and whether ogres should be made to sleep outside the front door or in the square.  They also discussed Yugherkug’s impending Cleansing:

– “Tomorrow’s the big day for your ogreson, isn’t it?”
– “It’s about time, ogresons are so ridiculous without a proper set of scales -- all those muscles showing through, it’s so indecent.”
– “And ogresons are so rowdy before their Cleansing”
– “Yes, it’s a shame they can’t be initiated at birth”
– “You’ve survived with him until now, what’s one more night?”

Eventually, the Council for Creation and Improvement drew its meeting to a noisy close and the ogresses filed out of the Roundbelly home.  Tazagthrog speedily cleared the table and gathered the leftover food.  He left another minuscule portion (by his reckoning) near Odessa and glanced briefly at her.  When she smiled at him, he immediately dropped his gaze and disappeared into the kitchen.  A few moments later, he hurried past her and out the door with a handful of food.  Odessa heard the rustling of hay as he lay down for the night.

Turgolga belched a few times, stood up unsteadily, and staggered to her bedroom.  She filled the doorframe with a perfectly sized obelisk and a few moments later, Odessa heard her crash into bed and start snoring.

Odessa walked to the front entrance and peered around the corner.  Tazagthrog lay still on his bed of hay, but as his eyes looked half-open, she wasn’t sure whether he was asleep.  A small ginger shape flashed past her and she turned around to see Trousers reclining on her backpack.  His bushy tail tapped her bag excitedly as he groomed his paws and stomach with energetic precision.

“Trousers!” she whispered as she lay down next to him, “where were you?  Are you alright?”

Trousers ceased his grooming and curled up in her arm, his face nestled under her chin.  “I have completed my scouting mission.”

Odessa squeezed him with delight.  “Go on, what did you find out?”

Trousers cleared his throat and commenced his report.

entry.title: LAMP Installation Woes, MariaDB, Ubuntu Installations
entry.content:
Hi,

Last night my installation of mysql did not go well, and I managed to do something strange to apt-get on my machine.  I suspect I failed to stop the mysql service before running apt-get remove. 
I ended up purging my AMP stack and re-installing it, but now when I run php -v I get some crazy output:

PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/xml.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/xml.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/dom.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/dom.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/gd.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/gd.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/simplexml.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/simplexml.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/wddx.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/wddx.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/xmlreader.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/xmlreader.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/xmlwriter.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/xmlwriter.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP Warning:  PHP Startup: Unable to load dynamic library '/usr/lib/php/20151012/xsl.so' - /usr/lib/php/20151012/xsl.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory in Unknown on line 0
PHP 7.0.8-0ubuntu0.16.04.1 (cli) ( NTS )
Copyright (c) 1997-2016 The PHP Group
Zend Engine v3.0.0, Copyright (c) 1998-2016 Zend Technologies
    with Zend OPcache v7.0.8-0ubuntu0.16.04.1, Copyright (c) 1999-2016, by Zend Technologies

So I'm going to wipe my machine and re-install Ubuntu.  (It was a fresh install anyway, so no big deal)

Come to think of it, maybe I should just install Ubuntu in a virtual machine.

No, I might as well have a fresh installation without any worries in the background.

I also thought of installing Ubuntu Server, which prompts the user to install the entire AMP stack in addition to all the other useful tools, but to be honest I'd end up installing the GUI, and I'd prefer to install the stack step by step on a machine I'm comfortable with.

So...
  1. Download Ubuntu Desktop 16.04.1
  2. Create an installation USB
  3. Re-install Ubuntu Desktop
  4. Install virtualbox
  5. Install Apache2
  6. Install MySQL
  7. Install PHP
Future tasks
  1. Learn how to install Ubuntu Server in a vbox from the command line
  2. Learn how to install Ubuntu Server in the cloud
Once I've got my rig up and running I'll get back to teaching myself the ins and outs of the LAMP stack.

-- Alex

entry.title: All Movement Is Resistance Training
entry.content:
I work at a standing desk.  When I type, in order to maintain good posture, I have to make sure my scapulae are retracted, my weight is distributed evenly, my head is in neutral position... Sound familiar?

I think all too often we ignore form and balance in everyday activities, to the detriment of our overall musculo-skeletal function.  Everyone pays attention to technique and form during the ten minutes of squats at the gym, but that same good form is absent during the nine hours at the keyboard in the office.

Think about it.
Commenting (It is Pixie) <3

entry.title: Goodbye, Facebook, For Now...
entry.content:
As per my last post on the topic, I have decided to deactivate my account on Facebook.

There are many reasons for this decision, each one as good as the next, but my primary reason is to give The Odessia project everything I've got.

From Monday to Friday, I endeavour to maintain the following schedule:
  1. Put in an hour of focused, creative writing on The Odessia before going to work;
  2. Work conscientiously at my full-time job;
  3. Train every day at the gym for at least an hour and a half;
  4. Cook all my meals and keep house;
  5. Put in at least half an hour of further work on The Odessia.
  6. Be ready for bed by no later than 21:00.
And with my keen interest in a range of topics and my penchant for arguing with people online, I simply can't find a way to remain on Facebook without compromising this routine.  To put it another way, MORE than being on Facebook, I want to work well, stay fit, eat healthily, and pursue my dream of being a professional writer.

In this light it's a very simple decision.

Looking back, I was uninterested in Facebook until I got into swing dancing, at which point it became useful to me as a way of quasi-befriending people within the circles I moved in and staying up to date with social gatherings.  Later, as I built up a presence on YouTube, Facebook gave me a way of interacting with my subscribers, which I greatly enjoyed.  Over the last year, I have used my personal Facebook account to broadcast my philosophical and political views.  This has brought about two felicitous consequences:
Firstly, a great reduction in the number of Leftist ideologues (feminists, socialists, etc) willing to associate with me online;
Secondly, a modest increase in online association with those whom I hold in high esteem.

Nevertheless, arguing about politics online takes up more of my time than I can spare.

So now, at the end of 2015, the reasons for being on Facebook have mostly fallen away.

In the absence of Facebook, those I wish to remain in touch with can do so easily by the other means; as to staying up to date with developments in the world, RSS, YouTube, and Google will cover my needs; and if I find I have time for debating online, I'm sure there is no shortage of ways to do that -- although I suspect that I will have better things to do for the foreseeable future.

And of course I don't rule out the possibility of returning to Facebook one day, but my intention is to leave it for good. 

When I am online, I want either to expand my horizons, absorb useful information, enjoy something beautiful, or create content. (Such as this post!)

Here are the steps I have followed to prepare for a successful disengagement from Facebook:
1. Consolidate my blogs into this one. 
2. Set up RSS for blogs and Facebook pages I should like to follow. 
3. Use Evernote for quick memos, rather than status updates. 
4. Add birthdays of my true friends to my Google calendar 
5. Have an active Google+ account
6. Download my Facebook content

My plan is to deactive my account on New Year's Day 2016, but depending on how things go, I might do it sooner.  If you'd like to get in touch with me and haven't got any of my alternative contact details, leave a comment on this blog or message me via my profile and I will get in touch with you.

Let me know what you think of this decision and whether it encourages you to return to a quieter, simpler, slower pace of online life.

entry.title: Chapter V: Timotheos
entry.content:
Shortly after Trousers went exploring, Odessa was roused by a simple, haunting melody in A Minor that drifted across the grass.  She followed the music back to the piano, where a young man was playing.  His long blonde hair cascaded down his back in a shower of perfect ringlets and his red beard was neatly trimmed.  


Odessa tiptoed towards the piano and stood off to the side to watch.  On the ivory stage of the keyboard, his hands jetéd and glisséd with practised ease.  He inclined his head towards the heavens, almost as if he were about to kiss the air.  The music washed over Odessa; she felt tingles down her spine and goosebumps on her skin; her cheeks felt very warm and she found herself having to breathe deeply.  The sunlight draped over him like an ethereal cloak.


He guided the song to its conclusion and ended on two deep A notes.  He bowed his head until the last drop of sound evaporated on the wind.  His hands drifted down to his lap, he raised his head, and stared into the distance.  Odessa held her breath.  “What’s wrong with me, why can’t I go say Hello?” she thought to herself.


The young man turned to get up and started when he saw her.  He tilted his head slightly.  “Hello there,” he said.  Odessa’s throat felt dry.  “Ah, hello.  I heard you playing, and I just arrived, and I thought I would come to hear, I mean listen…” she drew a breath and exhaled.  “What I mean to say is you play beautifully.”


He glanced down momentarily, and looked up at her with twinkling blue eyes.  “Thank you,” he replied.  “It’s such a lovely day, I thought it a shame not to enjoy the piano for a bit.”


“Oh yes, it’s a gorgeous day!” Odessa blurted out.  She blushed.


The young man walked up to her and extended his hand.  He shook her hand with a firm, gentle grasp; as their hands parted, his fingertips brushed her palm and spurt of heat flashed across her hand.   “Thank you for listening to my tinkering.  I hope it wasn’t too clumsy.”  Odessa made to reply, but no sound came out of her mouth.


“What’s your name?”


“Odessa.”


“That’s a charming name.  It means traveller, right?”


“Yes, you could say I grew up on the road.  My parents are travelling merchants and entertainers.  What’s your name?”


“Timotheos,” he said with a touch of embarrassment.


“That’s a grand name.”


“Yes,” he laughed.  “I think I still have to grow into it.”


He held his hands out and she placed her hands in his.  He gazed at her fingers as his thumbs squeezed the back of her hands, and his fingertips brushed her palms.


“You must play the piano too, you have the hands for it.”


“Not nearly as well as you though, just a couple of bits and pieces.”


He looked up and grinned with a hint of shyness at her compliment; the sun lent his curls a golden glow.  A warm wave radiated from his hands into hers, along her arms, down into her chest.  A large dark cloud blotted out the sun and the clearing fell into darkness, except for the piano which radiated with a faintly blue white light.  


Timotheos took Odessa into an intimate closed hold: cheek to cheek, chest to chest, his right arm around her side, his right hand firmly between her shoulder blades, her right hand in his left.  The piano played a slow, dreamy waltz; the trees around the clearing hummed a deep bass accompaniment, and tapped their branches together to form a rustling drumbeat.


Timotheos and Odessa floated on the music around the piano.  
The stepped side to side, forward and back, swayed and turned, stopped and went.  Odessa didn’t know the steps but he lead her through an array of moves and movements with nothing but a light touch on her back, the flick of his wrist, the tips of his fingers, and the irresistible sway of his shoulders and hips.  She marvelled at the way they moved together.  She had never encountered this dance or heard this music, they contained familiar elements but combined them in strange new ways.  The music died down and the sun came back out.


They ended in a close embrace.  Odessa pressed her cheek against his; she didn’t want to let go.  His hands dropped to her waist; her hands sought out his shoulders.  “It’s a pleasure to meet you, Odessa,” he purred.  He smelled of almonds and spice and his warm breath made her ears tingle.  His beard felt like soft English grass.  His lips brushed her cheek and her fingers dug into his shoulders slightly.


“Maybe you can play something else for me?” She whispered hopefully.


He hummed a sigh; she breathed in deeply and his smell rushed to her head.  “One day,” he said sadly.  “One day, when I’m free.”  He cupped her cheek in his hand and inclined his head towards hers; the warmth of his breath reached out to her; their lips came within a hair’s breadth of each other.  He stopped, sighed, and pressed his forehead to hers.  He stepped back and guided her hands to the bottom of his ribcage.  “Think kind, happy thoughts,” he said.  Odessa thought of hugs and purrs, whispered words, gentle gestures, and stolen kisses.  An electric blue light appeared on his chest and outlined her fingers.  He pulled her hands away and cradled them in his; the palms of her hands were imbued with an ephemeral blue light.


“You have the gift of a kind touch, Odessa.  You have a great power to share another’s pain.  Please be careful: there is only so much suffering you can draw into yourself.”


He let go of her, turned around, and disappeared down the path without a sound.  Odessa watched him leave.  A great heaviness overcame her limbs and her head felt like a helium balloon.  She pressed her hair to her face; she could still smell almonds and spice.  Her feet came unstuck and she shook her head as if to wake up from a dwaal.


Odessa took off down the path after him.  It meandered through the garden, up the hills, through a maze (at the centre of which stood the statue of a cat on a brick wall), over a footbridge across a brook, until it ended at the edge of the floating island, where a Victorian street lamp now stood patiently in front of Bridge #135.  Timotheos stepped on to the bridge, turned to face her, closed his eyes and placed his hands over his heart.  A cloud drifted across the bridge and when it floated away, Timotheos was gone.


Trousers returned to find Odessa sitting with her legs crossed, her hands over her heart, staring at the clouds on the horizon.  Trousers stepped on to her lap and nuzzled her throat.  She wrapped her arms around him and kissed his head.

As Bridge #135 carried them down through the sky, the piano in the clearing played a sad, wistful tune.

I can see all the references to collectivism coming through. The way the faces in the wall throw the typical arguments of socialist guilt at "Comrade", before he was ripped apart, was very creative. I'm genuinely keen to read chapter three, just to see if Odessa can get through without being torn apart! On I go...

Yo Gman, a bit of feedback after reading the first chapter:

First of all, I love your premise. From a technical standpoint, the many bridges scenario makes it very easy for you to have maximum creative freedom as the story develops, and if that's what you intended it for, I'd have to say you did a very good job!

I found your description in the early half of the chapter to be rather static however, I feel you could work on making it appear more fluid- an example:

-The paragraph describing Odessa's physical appearance has each sentence begin with "She" x2 "Her" x2 and "When She" x2. I am assuming this was intentional and that it's purpose was to lead up to the eventual break "But there was no-one that she especially loved anymore." However this, for me, read very 'list-like' until the penultimate sentence:"When she Daydreamed..." which I felt was executed very well, especially the use of the word "And" to begin the final sentence. I feel that the "Her" segments of the paragraph were the weakest.

This being said, I very much enjoyed the second half of the chapter (After the introduction of trousers) I like his whimsical concept!

entry.title: Chapter XIII: Tazagthrog's Scars
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/devosdelphin/3418388055/sizes/l 
Odessa grabbed her backpack and along with Trousers followed Tazagthrog through the city.  Ogres and ogresons were fast asleep in the hay; from some houses the sound of ogress chatter and laughter filtered through.  They arrived at the stairs to the Old Entrance; Tazagthrog ghosted up them and disappeared into the tunnel.  By the time Odessa and Trousers clambered to the top he was long gone.

By the light of her orb, Odessa followed the bright string she had left through the labyrinth to the back of the main cave.  The light from her orb faded as she stepped into the moonlight.  She put it in her pocket and tiptoed towards the Old Entrance, where Tazagthrog sat silently, staring out at the canyon.

“Odessa, what are you doing?” Trousers asked.  “Don’t let him see you!”

“Why not? He was gentle with you.”

“I know, but he came here to get away.  He didn't invite us here.”

“But he’s sad.”

“And what if he gets angry?”

“I don’t know.  But he needs someone to talk to.  Stay here and keep watch.”

Trousers wanted to pull her back, but he stayed behind in the shadows and watched her with frustration.  “Alright then, but be careful.”

Odessa approached Tazagthrog.  He spun around and towered over her.

“Who goes there?”

“It’s just me, Odessa.”

“Turgolga’s pet?”

“I'm not her pet,” Odessa said, “I'm a traveller.”

“Why did she let you follow me?”

“I don't think she knows I'm here.”

“Oh, I see.  Did anyone see you follow me?”

“I don’t think so.”

Tazagthrog picked up Odessa and held her up to his face.  His eyes were like stained glass windows and his fingers felt like anacondas.  His sulfurous breath made Odessa’s eyes water.

“Aren't you afraid of me?”

The orb pulsed warmly in Odessa's pocket; she looked down and saw that it glowed a gentle electric blue.  “I don’t think you’re as nasty as Turgolga says you are.”

“I’m not sure about that.”

He placed Odessa back on the ground and sat down.  He resumed staring into the canyon.  Odessa sat down next to him and followed his gaze to the gently moonlit rock.

“Are you happy that Yugherkug had his Cleansing today?”

“It had to be done.”

“But are you happy?”

“It doesn’t matter whether I’m happy or not.”

“It matters to me.”

Tazagthrog sighed and sank into silence.

“What was your Cleansing like?”

He pulled his feet in and wrapped his arms around his knees.  “I don’t remember much of it.  Turgolga was there; she delivered the knife to my mother.  The cutting hurts, but when the fire takes hold of you... nothing hurts much after that.” 

Odessa patted his arm.  “I’m sorry you had to go through that.  It doesn’t seem fair.”

“Life isn’t meant to be fair.”  His ears quivered in the moonlight.

“What was Turgolga like when you first met her?”

Tazagthrog’s mood lightened and he sat up straight.

“She was lovely -- I mean, she still is lovely, all ogresses are lovely -- but I remember when I first saw her.  She was tall and slender and very beautiful -- I mean, she’s even more beautiful now, ogresses are supposed to put on weight, but back then I thought she was very fine.  I remember once I stepped into her space in the square, and she could have punched my ear, but she just slapped and kicked me instead.  If her friends had seen that, they would have said she doesn't know how to hit an ogre, but I know she could have hurt me if if she wanted to.”

“Doesn’t it hurt when another ogre hits you?”

“Not much; you get used to it.”

“Is that because of your scales?”

“They help, especially against knives or fire.”

“Do the scales cover you entirely?”

“Almost, but I managed to keep one spot to myself.”

“May I see it?”

Tazagthrog remained silent.  Odessa pulled the orb from her pocket.  She held it up to Tazagthrog and its blue light grew brighter.  She moved it up along his arm across the front of his shoulder.  He pulled himself back from the edge and splayed his legs; she stepped over one leg and stood in front of him.  As she moved the light across his chest, a patch about the size of her hand in the middle of his chest glowed green. 

“You found it, Odessa.”

“Why do you keep it?  I thought ogres have to be tough.”

“I know I should burn it shut, but sometimes when I’m sad touching it makes me feel better.  If I lost this soft spot, I wouldn’t feel anything like that ever again.”

“Does Turgolga know about it?”

“No.”

“Why not?”

“I wanted to show it to her when I discovered it a few days after my Cleansing, but I didn’t want to disappoint her.  I wanted to be as tough as I could be for her; I wanted to deserve her.”

“She doesn’t seem very happy these days.”

“I know.  It’s my fault.  I do my best, but it never seems good enough.  She seemed different before my Cleansing; then again, maybe I’m the one that changed.”

His eyes shone like amber lamps from behind a craggy fortress.  His shoulders were stooped and a gentle groan escaped from him as he looked out into the canyon.

“Do you ever feel trapped behind all that armour?”

“Sometimes.  I miss being able to feel soft things against my skin.  I know an ogre isn't supposed to talk about such foolish things, but I wish I felt closer to Yugherkug and Yamizert; I wish... well... I wish I could...”

He lingered with his arms extended in front of him, searching for words that he had never learned and never had occasion to use.

“I don't think it's foolish at all.  We all need to be hugged sometimes.”

“Hugged?” Tazathrog asked as his hands dropped to his sides.

“Yes, it's when you put your arms around someone and he puts his arms around you.”  Odessa stepped up to Tazagthrog and stretched her arms across his oak-trunk abdomen.  Tazagthrog tensed and then relaxed.  His arms rose up and ever-so-gently ensconced her.

“You are so soft,” he remarked.

“You're not as hard as you look.”

“Do your people do this often?”  He whispered, as if afraid to break the spell.

“We do, although not often enough if you ask me.”

“How long do you, ah, hug each other for?”

“Sometimes, with really special people in our lives, we hug each other all night long.”

“Really?  And no-one punishes you for it?”

“No, we're safe.”

“I wonder what that would feel like.”

They held each for a little longer.  Odessa stepped back and looked up at this great creature, so immense and powerful, so vulnerable and forlorn.  She stepped forward and reached out to him.  As her hand pressed against the glowing green patch over his heart, he relaxed and slowly fell back on to the floor, like an old forest tree making its way back down to earth.

Odessa climbed on to his chest, knelt down, and placed her orb on his chest.  His scales were smooth and cool; his skin, like warm, rubbery velvet.  The patch glowed a fierce green as Odessa closed her eyes and leaned her weight in through her hands; suddenly, the orb melted into him and the patch changed to a brilliant electric blue.  The light spread across Tazagthrog’s chest, over his shoulders, down his arms, and into his fingers; it fanned out across his stomach and down his legs; it rushed up his neck and around his face.  The light grew brighter and brighter, whiter and whiter, until Tazagthrog and Odessa were engulfed by a cool white flame that filled the mouth of the cave.  In the middle of this noiseless explosion, Tazagthrog’s scales fell away and dissolved into ash.  The white light receded; in the darkness that took its place, Tazagthrog’s chest and limbs were crisscrossed with glowing blue scars.  Odessa sat up and placed her hands on her thighs.  She felt very tired all of a sudden.  She swayed, and toppled off Tazagthrog’s chest and on to the floor.  She struggled to stand up, stumbled a couple of paces, and then collapsed.

Trousers bolted out of the shadows.

“Odessa! Are you alright?”

He nuzzled her face and tried to wake her up, but Odessa lay still.

entry.title: Creative Commons, Free Culture, and a Modest Dream
entry.content:
The Odessia began, as is the case with much of my writing, with a dream.  When I was 19 years old, I woke up from a vivid dream and penned the following lines:
"Walking across a burning bridge, the fire consuming it behind me with every step I take, I am left with no option but to plod precariously along its creaking wooden gangplank.  Looking out across the dark depressive distance I see a line of fire-lit bridges to either side of me stretching out into the horizon..."
The story took me to the mountain, its inhabitants, and its creator.  My narrator escaped the mountain, but that is where the story ended, back in 2004.  I didn't know what the story meant or how to develop it.

Now, at the beginning of 2014, I have a dream, a goal, a sketch, maybe even a plan for the story.  No, it is not all laid out; no, I don't know how things will turn out for Odessa and Trousers, where they'll go, whom they'll meet, what they'll do, what they'll see.

However, there are a few matters of principle that will inform this project, for however long it may last.

Creative Commons and Free Culture

At the end of every chapter you will see this copyright blurb:
The Odessia by Alexander Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Based on a work at http://theodessia.blogspot.com/.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://theodessia.blogspot.com/.
As long as you link back to me (Alexander Garber) and/or this blog (http://www.theodessia.blogspot.com), this means a few things:
  1. The Odessia is published free of charge. (Gratis)
  2. You may share copies of The Odessia with your friends.
  3. You may share copies of The Odessia on your blog or  website.
  4. You may use portions of The Odessia in a non-commercial creative work of your own.
  5. You may use portions of The Odessia in a commercial creative work of your own.
  6. You may print copies of The Odessia and sell them for profit, without paying me royalties.
All of this is fine by me, as long as you link back to me (Alexander Garber) and/or this blog. (http://www.theodessia.blogspot.com)

I have no intention of making money from book sales, but I do have a perhaps foolishly optimistic hope that people will like this story and share it around.  If enough people enjoy my writing, this might open doors in the future, but at the very least all I ask is that you link back to me and my blog if you share my writing.

A Scaffold for Others

It is my heart's desire that some of you who enjoy these stories will use these ideas and my imagery for your own creations.  If we all link to this blog and share these stories, then my work can serve as a platform for your sketches, your graphic design work (if you'd like to create a template for the blog, for example), your music, your audio production talent -- I will record readings --, your voice acting,  your video production, your animation, your acting on camera, your live performance, your translations, your editing, your own writing.

You are more than welcome to publish your material under a traditional copyright licence or a more restrictive Creative Commons licence.  My work shall remain free (both gratis and libre) and whatever you create with it will do nothing but flatter, inspire, encourage, and delight me.

Community and Friendship

Finally, the creative process can be a lonely road, especially writing, which lends itself to and sometimes necessitates long periods of solitude.  Moreover, I can't commit myself to anything more than a release-when-ready publication schedule, which means that it might be a long while between chapters.
However, if these stories serve as the basis for a host of other creative ventures, including other people's writing, we could build a whole group, club, maybe even community around these ideas.  I know it sounds fantastical, but I've seen similar things happen and it would be a dream come true to bring something like this to life.

Join, Share, Create

Thank you for reading this far; I really appreciate your interest.  I have no idea where this adventure may lead me and you -- if you'll join me on these travels -- but then again, neither do Odessa and Trousers.

If all of this isn't really your cup of tea, that's OK; if you could share the link around though, that would verily warm my heart.

Let me know what you think in the comments below, subscribe to my blog, and join our Facebook group if you haven't done so already.  Until next time, a safe journey to you all.

entry.title: Pre-Release Chapters
entry.content:
One of the problems of having a weekly release schedule for The Odessia is that it gives me little time to solicit feedback and amend the text before publication.  I don't want to delay publishing a chapter, but making numerous changes to the chapter after it's posted is undesirable for many reasons -- most people want to read the final draft, it could wreak havoc with people's feed readers, etc.

Because your feedback is invaluable, the purpose of the following release schedule is to make the new chapters available to those who'd like to give me feedback -- I will love you for it! -- without blurting my half-baked writing across the internet.
  1. Draft
  2. Release Candidate (RC)
  3. Publication

Drafts to remain private

There is no good reason to make the drafts available to the public.

Release Candidates Available to the Public

Every week one new chapter shall be published to the blog, and the following week's chapter shall be added to a public folder on my Google Drive.  Click here to see this week's Release Candidate, i.e. the chapter to published on Friday-week.  (Not this Friday, but next Friday)

Published Chapters

Published chapters and a release schedule are available here.  Once a chapter has been officially published, it could still be amended, but I hope that by that point it'll be in good enough shape to require only minimal touch-ups.

Why should I be an editor?

Obviously, you will receive a king's ransom of virtual hugs from me if you critique a Release Candidate, which should be enough of a reason.
Also, I will happily mention you as an editor if you give me feedback or correct a typo.  This includes linking to your own blog or channel.
But I'd say it's mostly for the love.

entry.title: Chapter II: Meeting the Man
entry.content:
Chapter II: Meeting the Man


The crater was the size of a cricket oval; at its centre stood a lavish mansion.

Odessa scampered along the perimeter of the crater, looking for a way out.  She spotted an opening, but on closer inspection found no exit.  When she turned around, there was a man standing behind her.

Although the man was rather short, he was prepossessing in every other way.  He had hair like a news anchor and his face was almost impossibly smooth.  His slender frame was perfectly proportioned, and his small hands were decorated with red, manicured nails.  He wore a tailor-made navy blue suit and smart shoes with pointy toes.1

"I see you've made it all the way up my mountain," he said in a smooth, radiophonic voice, "most people are persuaded to join us a lot earlier.  Are you too good for us here?" he said in a somewhat joking manner.

He smiled like a game show host and stared directly into Odessa's eyes.  All the along the wall of the crater, a horde of staring faces with hollow eyes emerged, smiling with their mouths only.

Trousers peeked out from her backpack.  "Our summons instructed us to come see you."

"Really?" said the man. "Oh, my reputation precedes me!" The audience in the wall intoned words of approval.

- "Everyone wants to come here."
- "Coming here is a human right."
- "Everyone has a right to be treated equally."
- "Everyone has a right to be taken care of."

The man held his arms up and blew kisses to the faces all around, basking in their adoration, bowing and striking theatrical poses.

"What happened to Comrade?" Odessa asked, "What did he try to tell us? Why did they do that to him?"

The chorus died down; the man stopped his gesticulations and turned to face Odessa. His smile flickered and his hands clenched momentarily.

"Comrade was very sick, I am afraid," he said in a flat voice. "He was very confused and needed our help."

- "Yes, Comrade was selfish!"
- "We can't be selfish here."
- "We are all equal here."
- "Selfish people don't take care of each other."

"Are you the Man in the Mountain?" Odessa asked.

"Some call me that, but everyone here calls me Friend. We're all friends here, aren't we?"

- "Yes, we're all friends here."
- "We take care of each other."
- "No-one's better than anyone else."
- “We have coffee and cake here.”
- “Yes, coffee and cake.”

Odessa waited until the chorus died down. “Is this your mountain though? Everyone here looks up to you.”

The Man laughed at her compliment. “I don’t know about that,” he said with loud modesty, “I was merely the right man at the right time. I realised how unfair and selfish life was out there, and invited people to join me here, where everyone is equal and takes care of each other.”

- "Everyone wants to come here."
- "Coming here is a human right."
- "Everyone has a right to be treated equally."
- "Everyone has a right to be taken care of."
- “We have coffee and cake for everyone.”
- “Coffee and cake!”
- “Yes… coffee and cake for everyone!”

“Where do you get your coffee and cake from?”

The Man put his gameshow host smile back on. “From everyone, of course!”

Odessa felt her throat tighten. “I don’t understand.”

“It’s very simple, my dear woman,” the Man replied as hands sprouted from the floor around Odessa and started creeping towards her feet, “we all bring coffee and cake when we join, but some of us have to give up our coffee and cake for everyone else.”

The faces around the wall smiled and salivated.

- “Give us your coffee and cake!”
- “Don’t be selfish!”
- “We have a right to coffee and cake!”

Trousers whispered to Odessa, “What happens if someone wants to leave?  Comrade seemed pretty miserable about living here before the others tore him apart.”

Odessa pondered Trousers’ observation for a moment.

“But what if someone wants to leave?” she asked the Man.  “Surely some people would prefer to keep their coffee and cake.”

An expression of bewilderment wiped the Man’s smile off his face.  “What a strange idea, no-one wants to walk free. Life here is as good as it could be.”

“What do you mean, when you say that no-one wants to walk free?  Does that mean no-one here is free?” Odessa mused.  The creeping hands paused and perked up.

“Well, ah, no, I mean, that’s not right,” the Man stammered.  “What I meant to say is that no-one would want to leave.  Haha, what a ridiculous notion,” he laughed nervously.  “Yes, that’s it, no-one would want to leave!  Why would anyone want to leave a place that is perfect?” He turned to the wall for approval.  The faces stared at him blankly and one of the faces looked inquisitively at Odessa.  She skipped over the ring of hands around her and walked up to the inquiring face.

“What’s your name, Comrade?”

“It’s Comrade, like everyone else here.”

“Did you have a name before you came here?”

“Caleb.”

“But we don’t need to worry about something as self-centered as that.  We’re all friends here!” The Man interjected.

Odessa continued.  “Caleb, if you were free, you could leave or at least keep your own coffee and cake. But you’re stuck here, and you have to give up your coffee and cake if enough people want it, don’t you?”

“I suppose I’d have to, we mustn’t be selfish.”

“Come to think of, any of you here would have to give up yours if the others said so.”  She started pointing out faces around the wall, “You would have to give up your coffee and cake, and so would you, and so would you, and so would you over there!”

The faces that Odessa singled out looked around nervously as the attention of the crowd was drawn to them.  The mountain hushed and thousands of pairs of eyes turned to focus on Odessa.

"D-d-don't say that!" Caleb exclaimed, “we’re all free here, I’d give up my coffee and cake for the others, I’m not selfish.”

"But why is it selfish to keep your own coffee and cake? Are you really happy that all you do is allow someone else to walk all over you? Did you come here to be nothing more than a rock in a mountain?"  She turned back to the Man.  “And what about you?  You expect everyone else to give away theirs, but would you give up your coffee and cake for everyone else?”

Thousands of faces stared at Odessa in shocked silence. The Man tried grab her wrist but she shook him off with ease.  He stumbled back, regathered his composure and called out to the walls: "Come now, friends, enough of this selfish talk. We have everything we need, right? We're here for each other -- we love each other. Don't you remember how selfish life was before you came here?  Don't listen to this nasty woman, all she thinks about is herself, she just wants everyone to die in the middle of the street!"

Trousers whispered in Odessa's ear, "I see an opening down that way."
Odessa nodded and made a beeline towards the gap in the far end of the wall.

- "She's right, don't you see?"
- "She's selfish, don't listen to her."
- "But I've been thinking -- "
- "You've been thinking? Hey everyone, Comrade here has been thinking!"
- “It’s not Comrade, my name is Ethan.”
- “Yes, I’m tired of being called Comrade, it’s Zach to you.”
- “Yeah, I want to be called Hayden again.”
- “No, we’re all Comrade here!”
- “But I miss being called Brice.”
- "Selfish!"
- "You're selfish!
- "I'm not selfish, you’re selfish!”

Odessa quickened her pace. Arms shot out of the walls, snatching at faces, wrestling with each other. Rubbery grey, skeletal bodies poured out of the walls and collapsed on the floor, wheezing and wrestling and devouring each other. The mountain rumbled and swayed.

Odessa stopped at the opening; she couldn't make out what lay beyond. A small hand pulled at her hair -- "You! Look what you've done to my mountain!"

Trousers reared up from her backpack and slashed at the hand. It let go and Odessa wheeled around to see the Man.
But he was changed: his beautiful dark hair was dishevelled and patchy, revealing ugly spots and bumps on his head; his face was wrinkled and harsh; his eyes, wild and bloodshot; his teeth, yellow and sharp. His suit was shredded and barely covered his rubbery grey, flaccid body. Spittle formed in the corners of his snarling mouth and he nursed his wounded hand.

"I gave people what they asked for, everyone here was equal and we all took care of each other!" He exclaimed in a harsh, grating voice. "Now look at what you've done! No-one asked you to come here with your selfish ideas; people need to be protected from selfish ideas, otherwise everything will fall apart!"

He ran off, shouting, "Stop fighting, we mustn't fight! You all love me, don't you remember? We're all the same here!"

He tripped and fell on to a pile of fighting bodies. Startled by his arrival, they set upon him and he disappeared under a writhing mass of talons and teeth.

The mountain heaved.

“Are you ready, Trousers?”

“Ready when you are.”

She took a deep breath and jumped through the gap.

Odessa landed on a wooden sled that jutted out of the side of the mountain.  It broke off and she held on tight as it whizzed down the mountainside.  The mountain shuddered and cracked, and the floor of the crater dropped all the way to the ground.  Multitudes of bodies tumbled into the chasm, and the mountain collapsed in on itself.

Odessa and Trousers’ sled flew off the foot of the mountain and carried them through the air.  They sailed over a dark forest and landed in a pile of leaves in the middle of a clearing.  A path from the clearing lead to a cliff edge with a familiar white bridge that climbed into the sky. Under the Victorian street lamp was a sign that read "Bridge #15".

1 Thank you to Drew Zi for mentioning that smart shoes or boots with pointy toes are called winklepickers.↩
***
The Odessia by Alexander Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://theodessia.blogspot.com.au/

entry.title: Ma recette de la soupe légumes
entry.content:
Bonjour mes amis!

Aujourd'hui je voudrais partager avec vous une recette de soupe aux légumes.

Cette recette est très simple et les ingrédients ne sont pas chers.
Vous n'avez pas à utiliser cette liste d'ingrédients à la lettre; il est possible d'utiliser différents ingrédients et quantités.

Naturellement il y a beaucoup de légumes, mais il est trés important de ne pas oublier le bouillon et les épices aussi.
Je ne suis pas végétarien, mais je n'ai pas beaucoup d'expérience avec la soupe avec de la viande.  Si vous pensez que c'est une bonne idee d'ajouter de la viande, s'il vous plaît dites moi dans les commentaires ce que vous pensez.

Aussi, c'est ma première vidéo en français.  J'ai commencé à apprendre le français il y a deux mois, donc je m'excuse pour mes erreurs.

Bien!  Commençons!

J'aime le bouillon "Maggies" mais vous pouvez utiliser n'importe quel bouillon que vous aimez.
Voici une liste de légumes que je préfère utiliser:
  • Une kilogramme de carottes
  • Une citrouille
  • Un poireau
  • Un navet
  • Un radis
  • Un rutabaga
Ces ingrédientes sont naturellement doux; donc il est important d'être prudent avec les épices et particulièrement avec le sel.  Habituellement, je n'utilise qu'une pincée de sel dans ma soupe aux légumes, parce que je crois qu'il y a assez de sel dans le bouillon et dans les épices, mais naturellement c'est mon opinion, et vous pouvez experimenter pour apprendre quelle combinaison est la meilleure pour vous.

Avant que j'oublie, voici une liste des épices que j'aime utiliser -- elles sont très importantes!
  • le turméric
  • le paprika
  • "Lemon pepper" du supermarché
  • Du piment en poudre ou écrasé
Tous ces ingrédients ne sont pas trop chers et vous pouvez utiliser longtemps les épices.

Avant la préparation des légumes, ajoutez un peu d'eau dans une grande cocotte sur la cuisinière et activez le cuisinièr.  Je ne sais jamais combien de l'eau est necessaire avant d'ajouter des légumes, et si j'ajoute trop d'eau, je ne peux pas réduire la quantité d'eau après.

Ajoutez le bouillon et les épices dans la cocotte.  Si vous oubliez de le faire, si pouvez d'ajouter le bouillon et les épices à tout moment pendant la processus, mais est préférable d'ajouter ces ingrédients parce que le plus tôt vouz les ajoutez, le meilleur de la soupe aura un goût.

Les instructions pour la préparation des légumes:
  1. Laver tous les légumes à l'eau chaude.  Si vous avez un savon spécial pour l'alimentation, c'est une bonne idee d'en ajouter un peu à l'eau, mais il n'est pas nécessaire.  Il est possible de laver les légumes à l'eau froide, mais il est plus facile de couper les légumes quand on les lave à l'eau chaude.
  2. Pelez le navet et coupez le en petits morceaux.  Le navet est assez dur, donc plus vouz le coupez fin, moins il faudra de temps pour le cuire.  Ajoutez les morceaux du navet dans la cocotte.
  3. Vérifiez que vous lavez le poireau complétement.  Il y a souvent trop de saleté entre les couches du poireau, et vous ne voulez pas avoir de la saleté dans la soupe.  Si vous ne lavez pas le poireau complétement, vous pouvez éliminer la saleté de la surface de l'eau quand la soupe est en ébullition.  Aprés le lavage, pelez le poireau en gros morceaux.  Ajoutez les morceaux du poireau dans la cocotte.
  4. Couper les carottes en gros morceaux.  Il n'est pas nécessaire de peler les carottes, mais vous pouvez les peler si vous préfèrez.  Quand j'etais plus jeune, je pelais toujour les carottes, jusqu'à ce que je rencontre une belle femme qui ne pensait pas que c'était nécessaire.  Maintenant, je ne pense pas qu'il soit nécessaire non plus.  (C'est la vie parfois...)  Ajoutez les morceaux des carottes dans la cocotte.
  5. Pelez le radis et coupez le en gros morceaux.  Ajoutez les morceaux du radis dans la cocotte.
  6. Pelez le rutabaga et coupez le en gros morceaux.  Ajoutez les morceaux du rutabaga dans la cocotte.
  7. Si vous avez plus d'ingrédients, coupez les en petits morceaux si ils sont durs ou en gros morceaux si ils sont moux, et ajoutez les dans la cocotte.
Pendant la processus d'ajouter des légumes dans la cocotte, vérifièz que c'est assez d'eau pour couvrir tous les ingrédients.  Parce que nous commençons avec une petite quantité d'eau, l'eau va bouillir avant l'addition de tous les ingrédients.  Il n'est pas nécessaire de réduire la chaleur sur la cuisiniére avant d'addition de tous les ingrédients; en fait, aussi longtemps que vous avez assez d'eau, il est préférable.

Aprés de l'addition de tous les ingrédients, réduire la chaleur sur la cuisiniére. 
Laisser l'eau à mijoter pour deux heures.

Examinez la soupe de temps en temps, et ajoutez un peu d'épice si vous pensez qu'il nécessaire.
Durant la mijotage, vous pouvez rincer la vaisselle et les couverts.  Je sais, il n'est pas agréable et aussi un peu ennuyeux, mais il est important de cultiver des comportements responsables.

Aprés deux heures de mijotage, la soupe devrait être prêt.
 Je préfère de réduire la soupe en purée, mais il est bon sans le faire.  La goûx des légumes est naturellement un peu sucré, et avec des êpices et du sel du bouillon, la soupe est trés bon.

Un dernier tip:

Ajoutez un peu de tahini dans la soupe.  Le tahini donne la soupe une texture crémeuse.

Merci beaucoup pour regarder, et s'il vous plaît dites moi dans les commentaires ce que vous pensez.

Salut!

entry.title: Open Letter to Matt Hsu and Shane Dowd at the FAI Fix, Christmas 2015
entry.content:
http://www.thefaifix.com
The following is addressed to Matt Hsu and Shane Dowd, the creators of The FAI Fix, and their subscribers.

Dear Matt and Shane,

This is a quick note to say thank you for the FAI Fix and the superb resources, especially on YouTube.
Ever since I started following the FAI Fix and the FAI Fix for Athletes, I have enjoyed heretofore unimaginable improvements in my mobility -- glutes, adductors, hamstrings, quads, calves, external hip rotators, TFL, lower back, shoulders -- and have really no need anymore of physiotherapy, massage, chiropractic, etc.
My motto these days is this: "I don't need therapy, I just need a kettlebell."
And best of all: my FAI is a thing of the past.
This time last year I would not have believed I could enjoy a fraction of what I have achieved in two months of focused, almost daily application of the principles you expostulate and the exercises you prescribe.  I have modified many other exercises for my own purposes and plan to expound them on this blog next year, so watch this space.

I have never in my adult life or teenage years felt as free and easy as I do these days, and I achieve an appreciable increase in static passive flexibility almost every session.
When I started using the gym for my self-treatment, I was looked on as a reclusive oddball who spent a lot of time on the floor; these days, gym members and even some of the trainers now approach me for advice on flexibility and stretching, because they can see I'm on to something special.
I have never been so excited and motivated to train, and I can barely contain myself when I consider the plethora of movement forms I shall be able to safely explore in my new, stronger, more mobile body.

Yes, the FAI Fix works, and if you go about it consistently and intelligently, it will work wonders.
For updates on my journey out of FAI Fix and into mobility, please subscribe to this RSS feed:
http://alexandergarber.blogspot.com/feeds/posts/default/-/faijournal?alt=rss
Otherwise, you can subscribe to this blog in its entirety for musings on sundry topics according to my whim.

entry.title: The Odessia on YouTube
entry.content:
YouTube Script 

Hello, my name is Alex and I am the author of The Odessia, an online fantasy adventure novel about a girl named Odessa and her travelling companion, a ginger tomcat called Trousers.  Their journey begins at a set of magical bridges known as The Crossings, where Odessa follows Trousers across Bridge #90 to see The Man in the Mountain.  Their adventure will take them to weird and wonderful places, where they will meet all manner of strange and sometimes dangerous characters.

The Odessia is being published chapter by chapter on my blog [http://theodessia.blogspot.com.au], where I will also explain how I am going about this project and also elaborate my behind-the-scenes thoughts on the subject matter that these stories explore.

On this channel I will record readings of both the chapters and the blog, and might even upload some impromptu video blogs from time to time, so please subscribe to hear more.

There are a few things you should know about The Odessia.

Firstly, this project is released free under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (Also known as a Free Culture licence)

This basically means that I openly give you permission to share and use my stories in your own projects.  I don't ask for royalties; all I ask is that you link back to this blog.

Secondly, it is my heart's desire that you should shower me with your feedback.  This project is not subject to any of the usual limitations -- deadlines, word limit, informal censorship by a publisher -- but I need your help to continue improving.  Whether it's leaving a comment on a post or messaging me directly or critiquing my stories on your own blog or channel, you will be of invaluable help to me.

Thirdly, my dream for this project is that my work should serve as a platform to promote the creative work of other artists, writers, and content creators.  For example, if you contribute artwork based on the stories, this blog will help to expose new people to your artwork.  The same goes for translations, music, or anything else you can think of.  The more people who participate in this project, the more useful it will be to us all.

To find out more please visit the About page on my blog [http://theodessia.blogspot.com.au/2014/01/creative-commons-free-culture-and-dream.html] and don't forget to subscribe to this channel.

entry.title: Day 1 after Facebook and life is looking good
