entry.title: The Garden of Love by AJ Garber
entry.content:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/zedzap/9302868993/sizes/l/
Dedicated to my dear friends, Joël and Karen, on the first anniversary of their wedding. 
(Sunday, 2nd March 2014)

We went to the garden of love
And witnessed a living dream
A chapel was built in our midst
Of tenderness, honey and cream


A dance took place between us all
To the music of the breeze
In the sunlight’s speckled spotlight
We laughed and cried with ease


Our heartbeats clapped the rhythm
As the celebrant drew you near
The birds and wind held their breath
As your words rang true and clear


“I do, I do; we shall, we will”
The magic spell was cast
The birds resumed their chirping
Excited hands were clasped


In a circle in a house of love
Tears and kisses flowed
Words and songs brimmed with delight
Seeds of amity were sowed


Her right hand resting in his left
His arm had made its welcome claim
They were free to swing and twirl
No fear of falling in each other’s frame


Just the ever-present daydream
Of being swept right off their feet
With a tantalising movement
Executed to the beat
And indulgent recollection
Of the rare and cherished treat
Of being held
And being lead
And holding your attention


If only for a verse or two
I hold your gaze and you hold mine
And we’re amazed to see the twinkle of the star
That we wish upon in bed


A touch before we’d rest our heads
On our solitary pillows


And by the willow in our dream
We drift across a painted scene
While elderly couples recline
And reminisce and kiss


And as I drift back to the shore
I know there is a home for me
And as I come back from the road
I know there is a home for me
And as you reach the threshold
I feel your warmth reach out to me
And as you step inside our home
I hear your voice and it comforts me


And as we travel down this path
It matters not whereto
Mountains, valleys, desert ways
You have me and I have you.


But please ignore my wistful babble
No, please dismiss the things I said
My effervescent hopes
Must have gone straight to my head
Helped along for quite a while
By sips of port that make us smile
And with soft, illicit whispers
That rushed in like a tide
And left behind them blushing cheeks
And a crazy, foolish, silly thought
That caught in my mind
And wriggles around
And tugs at my shirt
And digs in my ribs
That maybe,
One day,
if you're free,
You might like to sit with me
And let me take your hand in mine
We'd put aside our charge of wine


And shrouded in each other's care
Underneath the starry skies
We could fill the summer air
With gentle whispers, hums, and sighs

entry.title: EC2 Set Up, Now To Set Up Jira!
entry.content:
It turns out that it's a pain to run Jira on a micro instance.
I have purchased a larger instance, which will cost me about $10 per month to run, but I consider it an investment.



I'm going to set up the LAMP stack and install Jira on it.
It's still on Ubuntu 14.04



Let's see if I can do a distro upgrade on SSH



I live on the edge...



I'll take the risk!



Upgrade complete



My Apache2 web server is alive!



It took me a while to understand the security, it should have been obvious but it's all part of the learning curve



An EC2 instance by default is open only on Port 22, i.e. SSH, so you can't log in to its server home page in the browser (of course!)
I had to create a new security group and open the necessary ports
But there it is:
http://52.62.253.103/
I shan't get to installing Jira today, but I'll do it tomorrow
I learned some new important things today about managing an Amazon EC2 instance so I'm happy

PHP is set up too; check it out!


And so is PHPMyAdmin

entry.title: Chapter VII: The City of Ogres
entry.content:
http://farm1.staticflickr.com/233/517997642_bff0aa7382_o.jpg

The tunnel ended at the top of a flight of gigantic steps carved into the wall of a sprawling quarry.  From their vantage point, Odessa and Trousers saw a subterranean metropolis of winding roads and cavernous, pot-shaped buildings.  The city was alive with ogres carrying loads on their shoulders, hewing rock, repairing roofs, cooking on great coal bonfires, carrying huge buckets of water into the houses, and climbing in and out of a network of tunnels.

“Welcome to our city,” Turgolga said proudly.  The sound of brass gongs rang out.  “Today’s Games are about to begin.”  The ogres in the streets downed tools and were joined by others from houses and tunnels: the horde made its way to an amphitheatre directly below Odessa and Trousers, at the bottom of the stairs, some waving green flags, some waving blue.

“That looks exciting!” Odessa exclaimed.

“I suppose so,” Turgolga sighed.  “Only an ogre can enjoy the same thing every day.”

“Don’t you like to watch the Games?”

“Some of the sillier ogresses find them amusing, but a decent ogress soon tires of them.  It’s nothing more than a bunch of ogres bashing each other’s heads in.  If you’ve seen it once you’ve seen it a thousand times.”

“Do you think we could watch the Games today?”

“Well, I guess you might find them novel, but I’ll have to carry you in.”

She walked down the tall stairs; Odessa and Trousers clambered down after her.

Turgolga motioned for them to climb into a large picnic basket that she had left by the steps.  “I can’t let you walk unprotected.”  They made their way to the upper level of the amphitheatre’s stands, which were mostly empty, save for a few young ogresses who were talking amongst themselves.
The lower level was packed with wildly excited ogres, who were jabbering and jostling for space.  The crowd was awash with blue and green.

Odessa and Trousers climbed out of the basket and sat next to Turgolga on the stone bench.
The other ogresses were about seven feet tall and had dark yellow, rubbery skin.  The ogres were at least eight feet tall, barrel chested with slightly rounded bellies and muscular, tree-trunk arms and legs, and were covered from head to toe in dark brown reptilian scales.  All the ogres were bald, had round orange or yellow eyes, and small, neatly shaped round ears.  They wore animal skin loincloths and were barefoot.  The ogresses wore animal skin skirts and tops or dresses, and leather sandals; they adorned themselves with all manner of trinkets, patterns, and markings.  As most of the adult ogresses were quite fat, their clothes did little more than accentuate their folds of flesh and the rotundity of their stomachs, which Odessa soon discovered they displayed with pride.  They had wiry black or grey hair past their long, pointed ears and slanted yellow eyes.

Two teams of large ogres filed into the centre of the amphitheatre, one group wearing blue armbands, the other wearing green.  They lined up against each other.  “Those are the Demes,” Turgolga pointed out, “half the ogres follow the Blues, half follow the Greens.”

“How do they decide which to follow?”

“It generally runs in families.  My son Yugerkug supports the Greens, like his, ahem, father, Tazagthrog.”

“What about you?”

“I suppose I would pick the Greens if I had to, but Council Member ogresses have better things to do than pay attention to what ogres get up to in the Dome.”

An announcer wearing a blue and green robe, waved theatrically to the crowd, which responded with raucous cheers and chants.  The announcer give a signal, a loud gong sounded, and the two groups proceeded to brawl ferociously until only one fighter with a green armband was left standing.  As the ogres in the centre did battle, the crowd erupted like enraged baboons, and fights broke out all around the stadium.  By the end of the official fight there were dazed ogres strewn about the stands.  For a while the noise died down as those left standing sat down for a rest, and after a while the rest of the ogres picked themselves up and groggily dusted themselves off.

“My goodness,” Odessa said, “do ogres always carry on like this?  Isn’t it dangerous for you and the other ogresses?”

“Ogres enjoy fighting and killing; it’s pretty much the only thing that makes them happy.”

“Did you say they enjoy killing?”

“Yes, that’s why the next Games are with animals.”

Odessa watched in horror as gargantuan pigs and bulls were lead into a pen in the amphitheatre.  The master of ceremonies gesticulated theatrically and pointed out random ogres from the crowd, who whooped with delight.  The volunteers lined up at a gate and when one of the animals was released from the holding pen, the nominated volunteer took off after it.  The animal, terrified by the roar of the crowd, ran around the sand frantically, trying to find a way out and kicking or biting whenever its hunter drew near.  One by one, each animal was chased down and beaten to death.  Sometimes when an animal was knocked down, the triumphant ogre put his fist through its skull, or ripped its head off, or held it up to the baying crowd before ripping out its jugular.  Each time an animal’s life was extinguished the spectators went wild with ecstasy, and occasionally an ogre from the crowd rushed into the centre, grabbed the animal’s corpse and flung it around like a ragdoll.  Others rushed to remove him, which led to another brawl, to the crowd’s delight.  Eventually, all the animals were killed, and their remains were carried off in large sacks by the proud volunteers.  The ogre horde streamed out of the amphitheatre, chanting and clapping and whooping like gorillas.  Silence and the smell of blood filled the air.

By this time, Odessa had climbed back into the basket, pale and weak with disgust.  Ogres bashing each other senseless was one thing, but torturing animals for sport?  She felt ill.  During the running of the bulls, Trousers stayed outside the basket and stood at full attention, his eyes wide open and his ears pricked up.  Odessa reached for him from the basket but he remained glued to the action until she pulled him in.  When she let go of him, he skipped out of the basket and continued watching attentively.

As they made their way through the streets, Odessa and Trousers peeked out of the basket.  The ogres had returned to work by then.  As Turgolga walked passed them, they instinctively stopped working, stooped their shoulders to bring themselves to her level, and dropped their gaze.  Turgolga cursed the ogres that didn’t move quickly enough out of her way, and when an ogre carrying a large rock brushed against her as he stepped aside, she wheeled around and slapped him powerfully across the face.  He rocked back, regained his balance, and quickly moved away.

“I suppose Turgolga has to be stern with them, otherwise they’d rip her apart,” Odessa mused.  “She must be brave to walk the streets with these nasty brutes about.”

As they passed a large square in the centre of town, Odessa and Trousers noticed groups of young ogres (known as ogresons) and young ogresses playing separately.  Both groups were almost as tall as adults; the ogresons’ skin was smooth and dark yellow, and they were much more slender than the adult males; unlike the adults, they all had large pointed ears and blue or green eyes.  The young ogresses were tall and lithe, with long braided or dreadlocked hair and almond-shaped yellow eyes.  The ogresons played boisterously -- wrestling, picking each other up, jumping acrobatically over each other.  The young ogresses mainly sat in circles and talked all at the same time.  An ogreson absentmindedly brushed against an ogress who was chatting with her friends; she leapt up and punched his ear.  He dropped to the ground clutching his head, and the ogresses and his own friends set upon him, screaming, kicking, and punching until he crawled away from their attacks.  He sat sulking for a while and massaged his wounded ear.  “It seems their ears are the only part of them that hurts,” Odessa remarked.  “I wonder why none of the adult ogres have pointed ears,” Trousers mused.

They arrived at a large round house that was carved entirely from solid rock.  Turgolga strode through the front door and deposited the basket on the floor.  Odessa and Trousers climbed out into a vast living room with a low table in the centre.  Straight in front was a doorway that led the bonfire in the backyard, to the left and to the right were bedrooms, immediately outside the front entrance Odessa had noticed two sections neatly covered with hay. 

“What’s the hay out the front for?”

“Don’t mind the mess over there,” Turgolga said with embarrassment, “that’s where the ogres sleep.

“Which ogres?”

“Tazagthrog and Yugerkug of course!  I know I should make them sleep in a ditch somewhere, but I’m too soft for my own good sometimes.”

“Don’t they sleep in the house?”

Turgolga snorted.  “What a strange idea!  Where do you imagine I’m supposed to put them?”

“Where I come from, you and Tazagthrog would sleep together, in the same bed.”

“Look here,” Turgolga said, with her hands on her hips, “I don’t know what sort of things you little people do, but I’m a respectable ogress.  According to the elder ogresses it borders on scandalous that I allowed Tazagthrog into my chamber on two occasions, especially after the first time produced an ogress.  Once Tazagthrog finished the lowly work on our home, his place has been either outside the front door or in the kitchen.  As I was saying, I’ve told them both a thousand times to keep their hay tidy, but they never listen.” 

She tutted in annoyance and then remembered her duties as hostess.

“At any rate, welcome to my home! I’m going to design a meal for Tazagthrog to make when he gets back from work, but first let me introduce you to my children.  Yamizert, Yugerkug, come here!  I’ve got a surprise for you!”

Yamizert, a young ogress, emerged from the bedroom on the left and Yugerkug, an ogreson, walked in through the front door.  Yamizert stood at her mother’s height, had her mother’s wiry hair, pointed ears, and slanted yellow eyes.  She was so slim (as far as ogresses were concerned) that her stomach barely protruded from under her top.  She looked suspiciously at Odessa.

“Ew! What is this ridiculous insect?  I wanted a cow to play with or at least something big enough to eat -- this, uh, this thing isn’t even worth a snack!”

“She’s not a ‘thing’ and she’s not for eating, Yamizert,” Turgolga explained, “she’s a -- what are you again?”

“I’m a woman,” Odessa said, “although some people think I’m still a girl.”

“What’s the difference?” Yamizert asked.

“It’s something to do with climbing trees,” Turgolga replied.  “Now, please, Yamizert, you can’t eat her and you can’t play with her either: I think she breaks easily.”

“Whatever she is, I think she’s silly.  I don’t know why you waste my time with this rubbish.”

“Now now, Yamizert,” Turgolga said patiently, “she’s a very interesting creature.  Please be careful with her, that’s all I ask.”

Yugerkug was Yamizert’s younger brother.  He was already the height of an adult ogre, although his limbs were not as powerfully built yet.  He had large pointed ears and his body and face were smooth except for a couple of small patches of reptilian scales on his arms and legs.  His round sea-blue eyes were bright with curiosity.  “Mother, she’s like a tiny hobgoblin! Wha’ we gonna call her?”  He asked as he took a step towards Odessa to a better look.

Turgolga quickly stepped up to Yugerkug and slapped him viciously across the face.  Yugerkug crashed on to the floor.  Odessa and Trousers ran to the far end of the room.  “Don’t you dare speak to me like that, you filthy toad!” She screamed.  “How dare you speak to an ogress in that tone of voice!”

Yugerkug squirmed on the floor and held his hands up to protect his face.  Turgolga grabbed his wrists in one hand punched him on the side with the other.  “Keep your mouth shut or I’ll give you a real hiding.  Speak to an ogress when you’re spoken to, understand?”

Yugerkug was not sure whether to answer or not, so he nodded his head energetically.  Turgolga kicked him in the ribs.  “And don’t you dare touch my pet woman, or you’ll be in serious trouble.  Now get out!”  Yugerkug scurried out of the house.

Turgolga stomped towards Odessa and Trousers and towered over them, her shoulders heaving, her nostrils flared.  She took a deep breath and smiled calmly.  “I’m sorry that he got so close to you.  I try so hard with him, but I can never be sure what he’ll get up to next.”

Odessa tried to keep her voice steady.  “I understand, I’ll try to be careful.”


The Odessia, a fantasy novel by Alexander J Garber is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License.
Permissions beyond the scope of this license may be available at http://www.theodessia.com.

For more information, check us out at http://www.theodessia.com or get in touch via the email form on Blogger, on Facebook or Google+, YouTube or Tumblr.

entry.title: Banana Biscuit Recipe
entry.content:
Banana Biscuit Recipe

INGREDIENTS

  • About 20 bananas
  • 1 cup of potato flour
  • 1/2 cup of almond meal
  • 1/2 cup of cinnamon
  • 1/2 cup of cocoa or cacao
  • 1 tablespoon of vanilla essence

PREPARATION

  1. Pre-heat the oven to 180 degree celsius.  If you intend to bake for longer than 90 minutes, bake at 160 degrees
  2. Line a baking tray with baking paper.  The thicklier you spread the mix, the longer it will take to bake through, and the more moist it will be in the centre.

INSTRUCTIONS

  1. Mash the bananas thoroughly in a large mixing bowl.  A potato masher comes in handy.
  2. Mix in the potato flour.
  3. Mix in the almond meal.
  4. Mix in the cinnamon.
  5. Mix in the cacao.
  6. Mix in the vanilla essence.
  7. Spoon the mix into the baking tray.  The recommended depth is about a centimetre.  If it fills to about an inch in depth, it is recommended to take out the tray after 90 minutes, allow to cool, and then slice it to a thickness of one centimetre and then put it back in for another 90 minutes.
  8. Alternatively, you can put the slices in a dehydrator.
  9. Allow to cool and keep in the fridge.
The banana biscuits are made without preservatives, but they should last about two weeks if stored in the fridge, although they usually get eaten by then.

If you re-heat them, the cinnamon and cocoa flavour will become more prominent.

entry.title: Chapter III: The Piano in the Park
entry.content:
Chapter III: The Piano in the Park



Bridge #15 took Odessa and her feline companion, Praetorius Pathfinder XII (known to his friends as Trousers) to an island in the clouds, and deposited them on a platform on the branch of a tall oak tree.  Trousers rode in Odessa’s bag as she climbed down a rope ladder.  When she reached the ground, she found herself in an English garden.  In the distance was a village on top of a hill.  The sunlight through the leaves created a speckled pattern on the manicured grass.  Odessa put away her jacket and top and felt a delicious shiver as the sun stroked her face and arms.

They followed a nearby gravel path through a small forest and into a clearing, at the centre of which stood a black piano.  There were three other paths that lead to this clearing and a large sign that read, “Play me, please.”  Two small children, a brother and a sister ran up to it and sat down together on the piano stool.  They banged away at the keys with noisy delight and their parents, who arrived soon after, said, “Well done, Sebastian, what will the little maestro think of next?” and “Yes, Esmerelda, that sounds beautiful!”

Odessa stood next to the piano and waited patiently for her turn.  She loved seeing little children at play, but she was also itching to get her hands on it; although she was not an accomplished pianist, anyone who plays knows how enticing those black-and-white keys can be.  Even a modest player like her could envelope herself in layers of music with nothing more than simple patterns and the sustain pedal.  Odessa was wont to overuse the sustain pedal, but out here in the forest, she intended to indulge this guilty pleasure.

“May I play the piano on my own?”  Esmerelda asked.

“Alright then,” her mother sighed.  “Sebastian, come here, you’ll have a turn after her.”

Sebastian folded his arms and pouted.  His mother put her hand on his arm and gently guided him off the piano stool.  His sister revelled in her unfettered access, and her little hands eagerly explored the keyboard in search of new keys to jump on.

Sebastian whined, “It’s not fair!” and tried to climb back up.  Esmerelda pushed him off the stool and recommenced playing.  Sebastian whined more loudly and sent his little fist into his sister’s back.  Within an instant both children were in tears.  Their mother looked at Odessa, pursed her lips, rolled her eyes, and sighed out of her nose.  “This is my life,” she said, “at least I’m never short of drama.”  She and her husband took the crying children off to the side.

Trousers jumped up on top of the piano and reclined above the middle of the keys.  Odessa sat down at the piano and played an upbeat, simple waltz; she bobbed her head a little and pulsed to the beat through her shoulders.  Esmerelda stopped crying and her parents allowed her to approach the piano.  Odessa noticed the girl mimicking her movements .  Her brother continued to protest: “No, it’s not fair, I wanna play!”

“Sebastian, if you don’t calm down and let this woman play in peace we’ll go home and you shan’t get to play the piano at all,” his father said in hushed tones.  Sebastian’s cries geared down to a steady sob.  “No, I wanna play it on my own!”

The mother mouthed an apology to Odessa; Odessa smiled and shrugged.  With only a couple of slips, which the casual listener never notices anyway, Odessa finished the song with a delighted trill.  Esmerelda giggled and clapped her hands.  Odessa turned to her and bowed her head.  Sebastian’s father continued to reason with him in vain: “Come on now, let’s listen to this woman play, she’s very good, isn’t she?”

Sebastian’s mother, embarrassed by her son’s behaviour, asked Odessa to play another song.

Odessa placed her hands on the keyboard and stopped.

“What’s the matter?” Trousers asked.

“I wish that little boy would stop making such a noise.  I haven’t had a chance to play for such a long time, and now that I’ve got this beautiful piano, I can’t play it in peace.”

“Maybe the boy is thinking along the same lines,” Trousers replied.

Odessa was a little annoyed that Trousers did not commiserate with her, and turned around to look at Sebastian.  He looked dejectedly at her with tears in his eyes.  She turned to Emerelda, whose excited grin had been replaced with an embarrassed frown when she had turned to see her brother.

“I wonder if there’s something I can do,” Odessa said to herself.  “Would you like to play with me, Esmerelda?”

Esmerelda nodded cautiously while looking at her mother.

“Oh you don’t need to do that, I’m sure she’ll keep quiet,” the mother said to Odessa.

“This next song needs a partner, maybe even two,” she replied with a conspiratorial smile.  The mother took a moment to register Odessa’s meaning and her face lit up.  “Oh, I see, yes, that’s a good idea.”  Odessa directed Esmerelda to sit on the right side of the seat.  She gave Esmerelda a simple treble pattern to play over and over, and then layered a progression of arpeggios and chords over it with the middle keys.  They played for a few bars and Esmerelda squealed, “Look, Mummy, I’m playing a tune!”

“Well done, Esmerelda, that’s wonderful!”

Sebastian stopped crying and walked up to the piano.  “Daddy, may I play too?”

Odessa nodded to the father and brought her ditty with Esmerelda to a close.  “That was grand, Esmerelda!” Odessa said, “Could you do that again?”  She nodded excitedly.  “Alright, now just wait a moment…”

She directed Sebastian to sit on her left and gave him a simple walking bass line in the same key as his sister’s treble pattern.  After a few attempts he got used to it.  “That’s it, Sebastian, keep on doing that; Esmerelda, repeat what you played for me...” After a bit of correction and encouragement, Sebastian and Esmerelda fell into the same rhythm.  Odessa proceeded to layer chords, arpeggios, trills, and other combinations between Sebastian’s bass line and Esmerelda’s treble pattern.  The two children concentrated quietly on their respective tasks and their parents held hands in breathless silence.  In a clearing in a forest in a garden in the sky, Odessa and her small companions made simple, happy music.  When the song had run its course, she placed her right hand on Esmerelda’s hands; the treble fell away; she placed her left hand on Sebastian’s hands; the bassline fell away; she played a final flourish and finished on a major chord.  The clearing hushed.  Odessa turned around and the parents clapped and shouted, “Bravo! Bravo! That was wonderful!”

Odessa directed her fellow players to stand up with her; they faced their audience hand in hand and took a bow.  She then placed Sebastian’s hand in Esmerelda’s and led them to their parents.  “Oh, that was marvellous,” the mother gushed.  “Thank you ever so much for putting up with them.”

“All I did was listen to what they were trying to say.  They wanted to make music and I showed them how they could do it together.”

“Tell me,” the father interjected, “are you a professional musician?  You could make a good money doing that sort of thing.”

“I can perform in front of a crowd, but I never had the discipline to master the piano.  I always liked to try lots of different things.”

“Well then,” he replied, “you must be very talented.  I could have been pretty good at the piano myself, but I focused on other things too, and now that we have a family, it’s hard to find the time.  Isn’t that right, darling?”  She nodded with an expression of weary sagacity on her face.  “Yes, it all changes when you have children.”

The family walked away hand in hand and Odessa sat back down at the piano.  Trousers hopped up on her lap.

“I tried to explain to them that I wasn’t putting up with the children, but rather listening to them.  Do you think they understood me, Trousers?”

“I suspect they listened to you as carefully as they do to their children.”

“In that case, I think they can expect a lot more drama in their lives.”

“I’m afraid so.”

Odessa gave Trousers a quick scratch behind the ears and concentrated on the piano.  She ran through her modest repertoire, stumbling here and there, adding a little flourish of her own on occasion.  Although she enjoyed performing acrobatics or theatre in front of a crowd, she found it harder to allow the music to take hold of her when she had an audience, at least a human one, that is.  When she finished playing, the birds chirped their applause and the trees around her whispered in approval.  By this time Trousers was snoozing contentedly on her lap, and it took her a while before she could bring herself to shift him.  Rousing a sleeping cat from one’s lap always takes time.

They followed a path that took her to a patch of grass next to a stream.  She lay down and Trousers settled in the small of her back.  She drifted off, listening to the song of the breeze.

entry.title: Hip Alignment and a Smartphone
entry.content: My training towards the side splits has brought to my attention...

Labas, Pasauli

Kas aš esu?

C̆ia nėra mano pirmasis lietuviškas įrašas, bet, tikiuosi, bus yra pirmasis naujoje ilgoje serijoje.
Leisk man prisistatyti. C̆ia, šiame bloge, mano vardas Aleksandras Keliauninkas, arba paparastai Keliauninkas. Ar aš lietuvis? Taip ir ne: tai priklauso nuo to, kas tavo nuomone tikras lietuvis yra. Apie šitą temą rašysiu kitame įrase.

Iš kur ǎs atvykau?

Pietų Afrika

Aš gimiau Pietų Afrikoje, gražiame mieste Pretorijoje, vieno trys sostinės Pietų Afrikos trys sostinės. Antrios sostinės Blumfontein (Bloemfontein) centre šalyje ir Keiptaunas (Cape Town) pietame šalyje.

Izraelis

Kai man buvo dešimt, mes persikėlėme nuo Pietų Afrikos į Izraelį, ir ten gyvenome

Anglija

Australija

S̆vietimas?

Nei mokinas, nei studentas esu. Neturiu šiuo momentu darbo, bet tikiuosi kad greitai vel pradėčiau dirbti. Aš mokau save būti programuotojas.

entry.title: Yi-shai Ri-bo: a-ḥat u-le-ta-mid
entry.content:
שׁוּב הָרֶגַע הַזֶּה , אֲנִי אַתָּה וְיִצְרִי
shuv ha-reg-a ha-ze,
a-ni və-a-ta və-yitz-ri

אֵין לִי פָּנִים לְהַפְנוֹת יוֹתֵר , גַּם לֹא תֵּרוּצִים
ein li pa-nim lə-haf-not yo-ter,
gam lo te-ru-tzim (gam lo te-ru-tzim!)

הָלַכְתִּי לְאִבּוּד בְּתוֹךְ שׁוּק הוֹמֶה אָדָם
və-ha-laḥ-ti lə-i-bud
bə-toḥ shuk ho-me a-dam

עָמֹק בְּתוֹךְ זוּטוֹ שֶׁל יָם
a-mok bə-toḥ zu-to shel yam

אֲבָל אֲנִי יוֹדֵעַ שֶׁלֹּא תִּתְיָאֵשׁ מִמֶּנִּי לְעוֹלָם
a-val a-ni yo-de-a
shə-lo ti-tya-esh mi-me-ni lə-o-lam

---

שׁוּב נַסְתִּי מַפְנֶיךָ כְּמוֹ אֶדְיוֹט בָּרַחְתִּי לְהָרִים
shuv nas-ti mi-pa-ne-ḥa
kmo i-dyot ba-raḥ-ti la-ha-rim

בָּנִיתִי מִסְּבִיבֵי חוֹמוֹת מְגַדְּלִים חַדְרֵי חֲדָרִים
ba-ni-ti mi-svi-vi ḥo-mot
mig-da-lim ḥad-rei ḥa-da-rim (ḥad-rei ḥa-da-rim)

הָאֱמֶת , אֲנִי בּוֹשׁ וְנִכְלָם
ha-e-met a-ni
bosh və-niḥ-lam

və-ech she-hu si-pak-ta bə-ya-di shuv

---

פִּזְמוֹן (piz-mon) [Chorus]

וַאֲנִי רוֹצֶה לַעֲשׂוֹת רְצוֹנְךָ כִּרְצוֹנְךָ
va-a-ni ro-tze la-a-sot

בֶּאֱמֶת וּבְתַמִּים ,אַחַת וּלְתָמִיד
be-e-met u-və-ta-mim,
a-ḥat u-lə-ta-mid

בְּלִי מְסָכִים בְּלִי מַסֵּכוֹת בְּלִי לִרְצוֹת לְרַצּוֹת
bli mə-sa-ḥim
bli ma-se-ḥot

בֶּאֱמֶת וּבְתַמִּים ,אַחַת וּלְתָמִיד
be-e-met u-və-ta-mim,
a-ḥat u-lə-ta-mid

---

This moment has come again, I and you and my urge
I don't have a face (space inside me) to turn away anymore, nor excuses either
And I lost myself in a market teeming with humanity
Deep inside the fisherman's net in the sea
But I know that You will never give up on me

And again I fled from your face, like a fool I escaped into the mountains
And built around myself tall walls, towers, and rooms within rooms
And the truth is I am embarrassed and ashamed of myself
There is not a thing that is invisible to Your eyes
Oh King of the Universe

And I want to act according to Your will for its own sake
In absolute truth and innocence, once and for all
Without masks or screens, with no desire merely to please
In truth and innocence, once and for all

The moment has come again, I, my heart, and my flesh
I have no words to speak anymore, not even rhymes to sing
Here, I have sliced myself before you into little pieces
I speak from up on high, but I do very little.

And I returned to my suffering, and I erred when I said:
Again I will not sin but instead return, again I will not sin but instead return,
And somehow You provided for me yet again...

entry.title: How To Attach the Bracket to a Provision-ISR TFT Digital Monitor
entry.content:
by Alexander Garber
To attach the bracket to a Provision-ISR TFT digital monitor, locate the headrest cover on the back of the monitor and prise it open with a flathead screwdriver.

Once the headrest backcover has been removed, locate the groove in the back of your TFT monitor.

Loosen the square nut on the bracket and then slide it up the groove in the back of the monitor.

Rotate the knob clockwise to tighten the nut and fix the bracket to the monitor.

entry.title: A Data-based Approach To Making A Career Decision
entry.content:
I spent some time working out the best way to arrange my career options in a CSV with the view of importing it into a MySQL database
My favoured approach is to list all the options and sub-options, criteria and sub-criteria, in lists in a data validity sheet, and then to populate the database with many lines of discreet data points
The alternatives all involved packing each line with many different variables, but my instinct tells me that a better principle is to change one variable per line
I can't quite express it, but my hunch is that a database set up with one change of variable per line is the way to go.

entry.title: The Story of My Engagement
entry.content:
NOTE: My fiancée wishes to stay out of the online limelight, and neither her real name nor her image shall appear in this or future posts.

I met my beloved at a libertarian meet-up in Melbourne in early 2015.  We chatted all night and befriended each other on Facebook, but didn't exchange messages for about a week or two thereafter.  At the time I was reading 'Paradise Lost' by John Milton and messaged her to share an especially good passage.  This led to our first date: at the Melbourne City Public Library, where we read from 'Paradise Lost' and some other poetry together -- Blake and Shakespeare, if I recall --, and then spent the rest of the evening at the Oriental Tea House.

Our courtship was not without difficulty, for who is not fallible?, but I believe we fell in love immediately and gradually came to realise that a great shift in our lives had come to pass.


On my birthday, 20th of May 2015, my beloved gave to me a beautiful hard-cover journal featuring etchings of William Blake's poetry.  In truth, the journal was too fine for me to fill with scrawls of incomplete thoughts, and I put it away until such time as I had something worthwhile to write in it.

On the birthday of my beloved last year, the seventh of January 2016, I finally realised what I wanted to write in the journal: a declaration of love and a proposal of marriage.  My first entry was on the twentieth of May 2016, and over the next fifty weeks, I gradually filled the journal with logs, love letters, transcriptions of poetry, original poems, and a short story.  I fell behind schedule during the winter and had to recalculate the number of pages per day to fill in order to have the journal ready by the seventh of January 2017.

In December of 2016 I ordered an engagement ring composed of a silver band and a sparkling emerald, which turned out to be the wrong size, and had a nervous wait for it to be resized by a local jeweller.
On the fifth of January, I had the ring.
On the sixth of January, the journal was complete.

My final Kanban ticket before the big day, now complete.
After eleven-dozen-and-ten pages of writing from the heart, the last two pages were my final declaration of love in French, Hebrew, Lithuanian, and English; and my proposal of marriage in all four languages.

The declaration of love:

Oui, mon amour, je vois bien l'essentiel avec le coeur: tu m'as trouvé et apprivoisé (bien que je suis encore un animal sauvage); tu es ma rose et je suis pour toujours responsable de toi.

כן, אהובתי, רואה אני היטב בלבי את הדבר החשוב באמת: מצאת אותי ואילפת אותי (אומנם נשאר אני חיית פרא): את השושנה שלי וערב אני לשלומתך לנצח.

Jo, mano meilé, aš svarbiausią dalyką matau: tu mane radai ir prisijaukinau (nors aš vis dar laukinis šveris esu); tu mano rože esi ir aš atsikingas amžinai už tave.

Yes, my love, I see the essential with my heart: thou didst find me and tame me (although I remain a savage beast at heart!); thou art my rose and I am forever responsible for thee.

And finally, the proposal of marriage:

[], ma chׂérie, mon miracle, je t'aimerai pour toujours.
Veux-tu m'épouser?

[אהובתי], יקירתי, נשמה שלי, אאהב אותך לנצח.
התהיי לי לאישה?
Progress chart at 100%!

[], mano meilė, mano stebuklas, aš tave amžinai mylėsiu.  Ar tekėsi už manęs?

[], my darling, my miracle, I thee shall forever love.  Wilt thou marry me?

The answers were:
Oui!
כן!
Jo!
Yes!

Where to from here?

My immediate goal is to get a start as a Ruby software developer, and to work in a location that allows me to move to Lara, Victoria, where my fiancée lives.  Our dream is to get married, have a family, and have many children.  My heart's desire is to provide for my future family, and it is the motive that drives all my endeavours.  My beloved is the embodiment of Christian virtue and every line of code I wrote brings me one step closer to the responsible, meaningful, intentional life I have always dreamed of, and which, at times in my despair I thought forever beyond my grasp.

But now it is within my grasp and the thing required of me is to study hard and work smart.

Now back to work and the next chapter of a wonderful life.

entry.title: Chapter IX: The Catacombs
entry.content:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/bichologo_errante/4860134538
Trousers worked his way up the rough stone wall of Turgolga’s house and climbed on to the thatched roof.  As the ogres’ dwellings were bunched together, he decided to explore the area by hopping across rooftops.  The adult ogres went mechanically about their day, carrying loads, breaking stones, building, repairing, cooking.  They moved with heavy deliberation and said very little.  Many of the ogres were accompanied by adolescent apprentices – a blacksmith banged away while his assistant pumped the bellows, two labourers, young and old, shuffled down the road with obelisks on their backs, a butcher slaughtered gigantic livestock while his assistant held them down.

Through the windows of some of the houses, Trousers saw groups of ogresses sitting in circles, talking animatedly, waving their arms and slapping their enormous thighs.  Here and there, little ogresons ran between houses and bounced around the open spaces; and young ogresses walked around in small groups, or sat in circles talking loudly at each other and slapping their trim thighs.

At the edge of the quarry a wide, dimly lit tunnel.  Trousers slipped behind some rocks near the entrance and peeked inside.  There was an inviting light in the distance.  He slipped inside and kept close to the walls.  Ogres transporting goods in clomped past those on their way out; no-one took any notice of Trousers as he sneaked through the shadows.  He emerged into the fresh air and made his way through the grass to a tall tree, scampered up its trunk, and surveyed the land.

The tunnel into the ogres’ city was halfway up a mountain, at the foot of which lay a sprawling, green, cultivated plateau.  Far into the horizon stretched neatly divided plots of land, some blanketed with crops, some filled with orchards, some covered with lush grass and populated by livestock.  Ogres trundled to and fro, working the land, carrying baskets of produce, and herding animals.  Some lay in the hot sun and snoozed, others sat on their haunches and quietly ate fistfuls of fresh food.  Trousers noticed that few of them talked to each other, and none of them sang.  An ogre came by and sat back against the trunk of Trousers' tree.  As there was nothing nearby for Trousers to jump on to, he paced carefully along the lower branches and got ready to scamper down the trunk behind the ogre's back.

“Take your time, I’ve come here for a nap,” the ogre said sleepily, looking ahead into the distance.

Trousers froze.  The ogre turned around and looked up at him.

“Hello, little thing.” the ogre said.

“Hello,” Trousers replied cautiously.

My name is Tazagthrog and I belong to Turgolga.  What's your name and whom do you belong to?”

“My name is Trousers and I don't belong to anyone.”

“I see, you haven't been selected by anyone yet.  Nice to meet you, Trousers.”  Tazagthrog settled back against the tree and stared into the distance.  “Feel free to come down, but don’t let the others see you -- they might want to play with you.”

“I’ll stay here for a while, if you don’t mind.”

“I don’t mind at all.”

Trousers climbed up a little higher.

“What sort of creature are you, Trousers?”

“I’m a cat.”

“And what does a cat do?”

“We do lots of things.  Some of us hunt mice and rats -- “

“What are mice and rats?”

“They’re little furry creatures --”

“ -- even smaller than you?”

“Yes, even smaller than we are.”

“How strange.  What else do you do?”

“Some of us own people -- “

“Is that creature you came with one of them?”

“Yes, she’s a person.  A young woman to be precise.”

“And what do you do with your people?”

“We don’t have to do very much with them, they’re usually very well behaved.  They bring us food and drink, and build houses for us, and set aside places for us to sleep, and are always happy to see us.  We put up with them and allow them to rub our bellies and that spot just above our tails which always feels splendid.”

“How do you acquire people?”

“Sometimes they are arranged for us before we are born; sometimes we have to scout out a suitable family and scratch at their door for a while.”

“Does that woman you came with belong to you?”

“In a way she does.  I received a summons to be her guide, so I have to watch out for her.”

Tazagthrog closed his eyes and Trousers watched him suspiciously from the top of the tree.

“Would you like to see something I made?”  Tazagthrog asked suddenly.

“Where?  Here?”

“No, over there,” Tazagthrog replied, pointing to a hill rising up from a forest in the distance.  “I keep ‘em in there.”

“I’m really not sure,” Trousers began, but Tazagthrog reached up to the branches and shook them.  The entire tree rocked as if in an earthquake, and Trousers dropped into Tazagthrog’s basket-like hand.

“Well, if you insist…” Trousers said.

Tazagthrog marched across the grass into the trees.  They arrived at a large boulder at the foot of the hill.  He shifted the boulder aside to reveal a tall, narrow tunnel, and took Trousers into the spacious cave at its end.  The cave contained a catacomb filled with clay jars.

Tazagthrog carefully extracted a few jars from the wall, each sealed with a neatly trimmed piece of leather that was secured with a string.  He held Trousers out in front of him and stared imposingly.  “You won’t run away.  Promise?”

“I promise.”  Tazagthrog put Trousers in one of the sections of the wall, up high.  Intrigued, Trousers watched as Tazagthrog undid the strings, removed the covers, and extracted a collection of animal-skin parchments.

“What are those, Tazagthrog?”

“These are my, ah… I don’t actually know what to call them, but I made ‘em,”  Tazagthrog replied bashfully.  He squatted down, unrolled the parchments and laid them on the ground with polished stones on their corners to keep them flat.  On each parchment was an exquisite sketch in black ink -- the landscape, a view of the city from up high, the face of a pretty young ogress with long braided hair and a cheeky grin, and a row of burning wooden crosses in the middle of an open space.  Each sketch had a crude, almost childlike quality to it, but there was no doubting the skill or care of the artist.

“Did you draw these?”

“Ah… well… yes.”

“These are fine sketches!”

“Sketches?”

“Yes, that’s what they are, aren’t they?”

“I don’t know.  I’ve never talked to anyone about them before.  I didn’t know they had a name.”

“So who taught you how to do this?”

When I discovered this place it already had lots of these.  It was smaller when I found it, but I ran out of space, so I widened it.  There were more of these, ah, sketches (his mouth rolled around the word carefully), and they're much better than my ones.  Also, I didn't know how to make the special black paint.”

“You mean the ink?”

“Yes, ink,” he said carefully, “sketch, ink, sketch, ink...” he murmured to himself.  “I worked in the coal mines so I can make a lot of... ink – “ Tazagthrog pointed to a large mound of black coal, “and when Megork Granitegut disappeared, I took over from him in tanning the leather, so I could make more of these special skins.”

“Do you mean parchments?”

“So that's what they're called! You are very clever.  How do you know all these names?”

“Where I come from, many people do what you do.”

“Really? Are they allowed to?  Don't they get in trouble?”

“Not usually.”

“But they must be punished.”

“It might happen, if someone important gets upset about a sketch – it has happened before.”

“I thought so!  Do they have to face the Council?”

“What do you mean?”

“If you do something wrong, you have to face the Council.  No-one wants to face the Council.”  Tazagthrog shuddered briefly as he stared into the distance.

They were silent for a while.

“Why did your friend disappear?”

“What's a friend?”

Trousers opened his mouth to reply, but stopped himself and thought carefully.

“Are there any other ogres who know about this place?”

“I don't think so.”

“Does that mean you haven't told anyone else about it?”

“I'm not supposed to be here.”

“Is there no other ogre you can show this place to?”

“I'm not supposed to be here.”

“What would happen if another ogre found you here?”

“Oh,” Tazagthrog's shoulders slumped, “I would have to face the Council.  You won't tell anyone, will you?”

“Of course not!” Trousers still didn't fancy his chances of escaping the cave.

Tazagthrog looked up at Trousers.  “What's a friend?”

Trousers considered his reply.  “A friend is someone you can tell a secret to, and he won't tell the Council.”

Tazagthrog stared intently at the floor.  “Does that mean you're my friend?”  He asked quietly.  Trousers paused and Tazagthrog looked up from the floor at him with wide open eyes and bated breath.  In that moment Trousers felt himself to be staring down at Tazagthrog from an imperious distance.

“Yes, Tazagthrog, you could say we are,” Trousers replied reassuringly.

As Tazagthrog allowed the response to sink in, a warm smile spread across his rough face.  He returned to his sketches.

“D'you like 'em?”

“They're superb! Tell me, why did the other ogre disappear?  Where did he go to?”

“No-one knows what happens to 'em.  I sometimes wish I could disappear too.”

“Why?”

I sometimes wonder if there isn’t something better, and besides, I don’t really count for much, no-one would miss me.  But then again, what could be better than having food to eat, and hay to sleep on, and an ogress to belong to?”

“Tell me more about these sketches, please,” he said.

Tazagthrog pointed to the landscape.  “This is my first, ah, sketch.  One of the goats strayed from the flock and I went up the hill to find him.  When I looked at the land from the top of the hill, it made me, ah…” Tazagthrog looked around the floor as if he lost something.  “It made me feel as if I’d eaten a big feast, only without food.”

“Do you mean to say it made you feel happy?”

“What does that mean?”

“I suppose you could say it’s when you are neither hungry nor thirsty, neither angry nor in pain; when all the things that bother you fade away and everything else feels good.”

“Yes! When I stood there looking at the land from the top of the hill, I didn't want to hurt or kill anyone, or even break anything.”

“Are you saying it felt even better than hunting?”

Tazagthrog sat down with his legs crossed and pondered this question.  “Better than hunting?  I don't know.  I always thought that hunting was the best.  It was different.  Hunting in the Dome is what we all dream of; but no-one ever talks about this quiet feeling.”

“And so you sketched the scene that made you feel happy, right?”

“Yes, happy,” He said slowly.  “And whenever I look at it, I feel that feeling again.”

“That means it's the best kind of sketch, Tazagthrog.”

Tazagthrog smiled with embarrassment, rolled up the parchment, and put it away.

“What about the sketch of the ogress?”

“That’s Turgolga,” Tazagthrog said with a wistful smile.

“Is that when she was younger?”

“Yes, the day I become hers.”

“She seemed lovely.”

“Yes, she’s perfect.  I don’t know why she chose me.”

“Why don’t you show her this?  I’m sure she’d love to see it.”

“I’m not supposed to be here.”  Tazagthrog rolled up the parchment and put it away too.  He made to roll up the rest.

“Your sketch of the city is incredible!”

Tazagthrog stopped and looked up at Trousers with a proud smile.  He sat back down next to his sketch.  “Thank you.  It took me a long time.  It's the view from the top of the stairs to the Old Entrance.  I like going there.  It’s quiet there.”

“I know what you mean.  Before I left my home I had a place that I liked to go to.  Sometimes I would sit and think; sometimes I’d just sit.”

“Yes, I sit here and think too,” Tazagthrog replied half to himself.  He looked up.  “Do friends sit and think together?”

“Yes, we certainly do.  Sometimes that’s the best thing friends can do.”

“You’re a good friend then, little Trousers.”

“You're a good friend too, Tazagthrog.”

entry.title: Review of Jacob Nadav's Bellyproof Fat-loss Programme
entry.content:
This is a review of the Bellyproof fat-loss programme, developed by Jacob Nadav of Movement First Personal Training.

I completed the Bellyproof programme today (31st July 2019), having started on the 17th June 2019, and will share my results and thoughts.

NOTE: I am not affiliated in any way with Bellyproof, Jacob Nadav, or Movement First Personal Training.  This is nothing more than an impartial review from a satisfied customer of the programme.  You can take it or leave it.

6½ weeks of early starts and dietary discipline
Naturally, before we get into all of that, let's look at the Before and After photos.

Here I am at an unhappily chubby 83.5kg (184 lbs)



And here I am, 6½ weeks later, at a much happier 78.8kg (173 lbs)



As you can tell from the poor quality of the photography, these photographs are not touched up in any way.

Starting weight: 83.5kg
Current weight: 78.8kg
Weight loss: 4.7kg (10.3 lbs)

I don't have the most precise figures for BMI and muscle mass, but of the following I am confident:

  1. I think I'm more toned, but I believe I neither gained nor lost muscle.
  2. I am well hydrated, so I haven't cut any water weight.
  3. My glycogen levels are not depleted.
  4. I have gone down in trouser size from 34 to 32.

In other ways, as my wife will attest, I am in noticeably better shape too ;-)

Therefore, of the 4.7kg (10.3 lbs) lost, I believe the bulk of it is fat.

What Worked

Tactical Intermittent Fasting

I had been practising intermittent fasting for years before the Bellyproof programme, but the LION intermittent fasting protocol made all the difference.  Whereas before I fasted intermittently simply to eat less, the Bellyproof-LION protocol uses intermittent fasting to promote breaking fat and burning fat.

Read through the explanation carefully: it's the deceptively simple key to the genius of Jacob Nadav's programme: https://bellyproof.com/intermittent-fasting/

Cutting Carbohydrates, Not Calories

I have never been one to bother with complicated systems for diet and exercise.  It's too much work and it shouldn't be so hard, unless perhaps you are an elite athlete, to whom a full-time nutritionist is assigned.

So the Bellyproof approach of simply restricting your daily carbohydrate intake works terrifically.  In reality, there is only so much fat and protein you can eat before you feel ill, and you soon understand why it is so important to load up on green vegetables.

As with intermittent fasting, I already was in the habit of not eating grains and eating relatively few carbohydrate-heavy foods, but having a specific daily quota of grams of carbohydrates helped a lot with food selection and portion sizes.  I also have to mention that my wife supported me indispensibly in this and made sure to prepare delicious meals that were very low in carbohydrates.

Breaking Fat Before Burning It

If you don't yet understand the difference between lipolysis and oxidation, then the best place to start is this blog post: https://bellyproof.com/intermittent-fasting-results-hiit-workouts-and-sweat/

It is thanks to Jacob Nadav's entertaining and informative videos and posts that I learned this distinction, and I cannot stress its importance enough.  Once you understand what you need to do to promote fat breaking and fat burning respectively, everything falls into place.

The Workouts

The workouts are composed of interesting, technical, enjoyable exercises that not only promote lipolysis, but are excellent on their own merits.  I plan to add many of them to my regular workouts from now on.

During the programme, I tried to increase the load for every exercise, every workout.  I started most resistance exercises with an 8kg kettlebell, and by the end I was doing lunges with an 18kg kettlebell, the Humpty Dumpty world cup with 16kg, the Bulgarian split squat with 16kg, and the Turkish get-up with 22kg.  On many occasions I pushed myself to the point of feeling nauseated and kept my rest time between sets to a bare minimum.  Hand on heart, there was not a single workout at the end of which I felt I could have pushed harder.

Gut Health

Besides losing quite a bit of fat, programme's recommendations for gut health are efficacious.  I can't say how much of this contributed to my fat loss, but I can say that I feel much happier and healthier for making watir kefir at home -- it's really easy! -- and addressing gut health.  I suffer appreciably less from bloating and other digestive ailments.

Where I Struggled

Early Starts

Owing to a very long daily commute, I had to get up at 04:15AM to give myself enough time to complete the workouts, which meant that I got home from work around 18:15.  Not only did that mean I had a 14-hour day a couple times a week, but I had to eat both lunch and supper at work on the day before a workout.  Consequently, it wasn't feasible for me to do five workouts per week, so I switched to four workouts after the first week.

It also didn't help matters that June-July is the middle of the Southern Hemisphere winter.  It meant rugging up, defrosting my car's windscreen, driving with the windows down for visibility, an unheated gym, a biting cold overhead bar, cold kettle bells, etc.  But if you want something enough, you just push on.  Also, there's something satisfying about warming up in a chilly gym and seeing the steam come off you as you exercise.  And I warmed up pretty quickly, so it really only amounted to a few minutes of discomfort each time.

Turning Off Screens At Night

I don't have an excuse, I just like to read a bit and watch a few videos before I go to sleep.  I wear blue-light blocking protective glasses in bed, and try to keep the screen time to a mininum, but I failed on that score.  How much of a difference it made to the quality of my sleep is hard to say, but I really should get out of the habit.

Black Coffee in the Morning

I tried it a few times, but it tasted vile and made me want to vomit when I exercised.  Instead, I took a couple of caffeine tablets (No Doze) with three glasses of water in the morning.

4-5 Litres of Water per Day

I didn't truly understand the importance of drinking so much water until later in the programme, and sometimes I forgot to keep on drinking.  I reckon I averaged about three litres a day, and made a record number of visits to the toilet.  Goodness knows what my colleagues at work must think.

Final Thoughts

I looked into many different programmes, but Bellyproof is the only one that comprehensively addresses all the barriers to fat loss -- exercise, diet, insulin levels, gut health, etc.

This programme is not for the faint of heart: it is for those who have the determination, discipline, and courage to put their faith in a comprehensive fat-loss solution.  I had tried and failed many times before, but I really wanted to make it work, and even though it's been tough with my work schedule and commute, and there were times when I was tempted to eat the wrong foods or simply stay in bed, I bore in mind that every day of the programme counts, both workout and rest days.  Every piece of cake not eaten, every workout completed with maximal effort -- it all counted in the end.

Where to from here?

I'll give myself a couple of weeks of a less gruelling schedule.  I have many other goals for physical training, especially in the realm of strength and flexibility, so I'll reassess and define some new goals.  I'll enjoy eating some fruit.  I'll continue to practise intermittent fasting.

And I expect in the not-too-distant future, I'll do the programme again.  Now that I know it works, it would be amazing to lose more fat and get a six-pack.  Two months ago, having abs seemed like a fantasy, but thanks to Bellyproof, I know I can do it.
